description: Excel 2016 Advanced explores ways to enhance Excel workbooks with topics in analyzing data, collaborating and workbook security, and adding graphical elements. This series covers important Excel functionality such as format as table, conditional formatting, shared workbooks and tracked changes, and data validation. While Excel 2016 Advanced is a continuation from the Excel 2016 Essentials series, it can be viewed as a standalone show for users looking to excel to the next level of skills.

episodes.description: Excel 2016 Advanced explores ways to enhance Excel workbooks with topics in analyzing data, collaborating and workbook security, and adding graphical elements. This series covers important Excel functionality such as format as table, conditional formatting, shared workbooks and tracked changes, and data validation. While Excel 2016 Advanced is a continuation from the Excel 2016 Essentials series, it can be viewed as a standalone show for users looking to excel to the next level of skills.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.616 --> 00:00:14.559
Hello everyone,
my name is Vaughn Smith, and

3
00:00:14.559 --> 00:00:17.432

4
00:00:17.432 --> 00:00:20.249
In this course overview,
we're going to be going over, well,

5
00:00:20.249 --> 00:00:23.380
exactly what we're gonna cover
in this particular series.

6
00:00:23.380 --> 00:00:26.840
Who is the target audience, what you might
need to know before you get started,

7
00:00:26.840 --> 00:00:29.970
and any extra tidbits that I have for you.

8
00:00:29.970 --> 00:00:32.720
So we have three main
topics within this series.

9
00:00:32.720 --> 00:00:37.330
We have analyze data, graphical elements,
and collaborate and security.

10
00:00:37.330 --> 00:00:42.040
In the analyze data topics we're gonna
go over things that a lot of your

11
00:00:42.040 --> 00:00:44.380
Excel users are wanting to know about.

12
00:00:44.380 --> 00:00:46.080
Once you get past the, okay,

13
00:00:46.080 --> 00:00:51.090
I know how to enter information in to
cells, now I need to analyze the data.

14
00:00:51.090 --> 00:00:55.900
I need to do things like sort and filter,
I need to do conditional formating,

15
00:00:55.900 --> 00:01:00.240
which is really cool to be able to pull
things out of it in a visual format sense.

16
00:01:00.240 --> 00:01:02.090
How do I make sub totals?

17
00:01:02.090 --> 00:01:03.940
How do I create outlines?

18
00:01:03.940 --> 00:01:09.520

me to look at the data and be able to

20
00:01:15.550 --> 00:01:18.410
Formatting as a table,
one of my favorite things.

21
00:01:18.410 --> 00:01:20.890
I use tables all the time in Excel,

22
00:01:20.890 --> 00:01:23.740
I think it's probably one
of my favorite features.

23
00:01:23.740 --> 00:01:25.313

24
00:01:25.313 --> 00:01:27.535
The What-If Analysis tools,

25

this is where we're gonna go over

and using the Goal Seek functionality

27
00:01:38.402 --> 00:01:41.731
We're gonna consolidate data,
we're gonna remove duplicates, and

28

we're also going to do

29

Now, this particular series is not

You're gonna be like, but this is Excel,

42
00:02:33.330 --> 00:02:38.450

45

That will apply over into

But we will get into
some SmartArt as well,

really get your that all of

50

58

59

60

62

00:04:22.470 --> 00:04:26.750

00:04:40.020 --> 00:04:40.940

77
00:04:53.570 --> 00:04:55.820

78
00:04:55.820 --> 00:05:01.540

79

82
00:05:09.930 --> 00:05:12.780
And if ever we need to

00:05:44.200 --> 00:05:49.350
Like, you have a couple base knowledge

93

94
00:05:54.710 --> 00:05:55.400

101
00:06:23.221 --> 00:06:27.550

102
00:06:27.550 --> 00:06:31.887
[LAUGH] What that means is
there's multiple ways to do

104

105

106
00:06:43.460 --> 00:06:46.940
And so if I'm doing it one way, there
might be another way of doing it, and

107
00:06:46.940 --> 00:06:48.920
that's totally valid.

108
00:06:48.920 --> 00:06:53.840
Updates happen, and man, they can mess

109
00:06:53.840 --> 00:06:55.940
and updates and
then your buttons move around, and

110
00:06:55.940 --> 00:07:00.480
things like the shared workbooks

111
00:07:00.480 --> 00:07:03.750
It does they just took it away,
they took it off the ribbon.

112
00:07:03.750 --> 00:07:11.260
It's not in the actual menus, you have
to go hunt and pick it, so that happens.

113
00:07:11.260 --> 00:07:12.710
And always being able to search for

114
00:07:12.710 --> 00:07:17.000

search engine that you want.

115
00:07:17.000 --> 00:07:20.870
You can find it, the Microsoft Help

116
00:07:20.870 --> 00:07:25.800
there's tons of resources out there
to help answer your questions.

117
00:07:25.800 --> 00:07:27.820
Everybody uses Excel for
different reasons, okay?

118
00:07:27.820 --> 00:07:31.660
So I cover all the different
things that Excel can do.

119
00:07:31.660 --> 00:07:33.711
Some of it you might not have any use for,
and

120
00:07:33.711 --> 00:07:37.055
that's totally fine cuz we all use
it in a little bit different manner.

121
00:07:37.055 --> 00:07:43.620
But for the most part, in this episode and
in how we learn, have fun.

122
00:07:43.620 --> 00:07:47.740
Have fun learning,
follow along, and hopefully

123
00:07:47.740 --> 00:07:52.060
the learning will make using Excel more
fun, and you won't be as frustrated.

124
00:07:52.060 --> 00:07:56.349
So please stick around, and we'll see
you in some episodes very shortly.

125
00:07:56.349 --> 00:08:01.973
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Vonne demonstrate how to analyze data using sort and filter functions in Excel 2016 for Mac. Sorting changes the order of all your data either by date, price, or alphabetically. Filter shows data based on your criteria. They also explore some more advanced techniques with custom sorts and custom filters.
episodes.title: Sort and Filter

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Vonne explore conditional formatting which allows you to automatically apply formats to a cell or range of cells based on cell values. They demonstrate the different types of rules and how to customize formatting.
episodes.title: Conditional Formatting

00:17:19.335 --> 00:17:19.889
>> Okay.

308
00:17:19.889 --> 00:17:20.673
>> Yeah, exactly.

309
00:17:20.673 --> 00:17:21.887
We can totally do that.

310
00:17:21.887 --> 00:17:25.430
So, why don't we come back and
show you that like, like you were saying,

311
00:17:25.430 --> 00:17:28.806
I've already got some rules applied
to this particular worksheet and

312
00:17:28.806 --> 00:17:30.141
I don't want that purple.

313
00:17:30.141 --> 00:17:30.935
That's what you're asking about right?

314
00:17:30.935 --> 00:17:31.550
>> Yep, definitely.

315
00:17:31.550 --> 00:17:34.088
>> Perfect, so I wanna change this.

316
00:17:34.088 --> 00:17:37.830
Now, I could clear it and
redo it, but it's already applied.

317
00:17:37.830 --> 00:17:41.177
So you can manage your rules.

318
00:17:41.177 --> 00:17:42.680
So I've got a couple on here.

319
00:17:42.680 --> 00:17:45.500
We've got the red, we've got the green,
we've got the purple.

320
00:17:45.500 --> 00:17:48.410
So if I come over here,
whoops well let's go ahead and

321
00:17:48.410 --> 00:17:50.390
click into the cell first of all.

322
00:17:50.390 --> 00:17:53.111
Actually, you know what, I think I
will select it here, there we go.

323
00:17:53.111 --> 00:17:55.370
Now we go ahead and
manage the rules, see there we go.

324
00:17:55.370 --> 00:18:00.270
Now I had to make a selection
where it was pulling

325
00:18:00.270 --> 00:18:02.570
all the rules that I had on my sheet.

326
00:18:02.570 --> 00:18:04.020
So let's back up.

327
00:18:04.020 --> 00:18:07.831
To make sure that I got that right,
okay, we can probably go ahead and

328
00:18:07.831 --> 00:18:11.578
select the whole worksheet,
cuz then when I go ahead and manage it,

329
00:18:11.578 --> 00:18:15.298
it's gonna pull all the rules that
are applied in that worksheet.

330
00:18:15.298 --> 00:18:19.501
So that might be something you'd wanna do,
because just you saw me do it.

331
00:18:19.501 --> 00:18:21.310
I was like, wait,
I know there's other rules in here.

332
00:18:21.310 --> 00:18:23.665
Why isn't, I need to select it.

333
00:18:23.665 --> 00:18:25.387
[NOISE] Okay, that sounds good.

334
00:18:25.387 --> 00:18:28.843
So you're gonna see that I've
got a rule for duplicate values,

335
00:18:28.843 --> 00:18:33.580
cells that contain street, or ST, and then
I have cell value that is greater than 50.

336
00:18:33.580 --> 00:18:37.570
Okay, I don't want it to be purple, or
I don't want this to be red anymore.

337
00:18:37.570 --> 00:18:42.544
So if you click on it, notice that if
I can come down here to edit the rule,

338
00:18:42.544 --> 00:18:46.946
so I select the rule that I want it to,
and then I go to edit, and so

339
00:18:46.946 --> 00:18:51.950
now I can come back in here, and
we will change this to a different color.

340
00:18:51.950 --> 00:18:53.518
What color do you want there, Wes?

341
00:18:53.518 --> 00:18:55.090
>> Green.
That's my other favorite.

342
00:18:55.090 --> 00:18:58.720
>> All right, let's go with green, and
you know what, I'm gonna go ahead and

343
00:18:58.720 --> 00:19:01.895
make it a super bright,
well that's not, it's kind of sea foam,

344
00:19:01.895 --> 00:19:05.095
but guess what, you got the first part,
I'll take the rest of it.

345
00:19:05.095 --> 00:19:06.028
[LAUGH]
>> That's okay.

346
00:19:06.028 --> 00:19:06.670
I like the water.

347
00:19:06.670 --> 00:19:10.798
>> So we click OK, or
actually we got to click OK here first,

348
00:19:10.798 --> 00:19:13.206
sorry, and then we click OK, and

349
00:19:13.206 --> 00:19:18.714
now you can see that everything that
was purple is now seafoam green, okay?

350
00:19:18.714 --> 00:19:21.738
So yes, you can go back and
manage your rules after the fact

351
00:19:21.738 --> 00:19:25.897
if you wanted to change them, and you
don't have to go through the whole thing.

352
00:19:25.897 --> 00:19:28.720
So I showed you the couple different ways,
but it is a little bit nicer.

353
00:19:28.720 --> 00:19:32.655
Just remember to select the whole
worksheet, cuz it makes it a lot easier,

354
00:19:32.655 --> 00:19:37.277
otherwise you think that it's not managing
anything, because if I'm right here, and

355
00:19:37.277 --> 00:19:41.710
I go into Manage Rules, it's gonna show me
nothing, cuz I don't have any cells that

356
00:19:41.710 --> 00:19:45.236
actually have conditional formatting
selected for me to manage.

357
00:19:45.236 --> 00:19:46.710
So, there we go.

358
00:19:46.710 --> 00:19:51.230
So you can see that conditional formatting
is pretty straightforward once you

359
00:19:51.230 --> 00:19:55.200
get the idea, make your selection,
go ahead and set your criteria,

360
00:19:55.200 --> 00:19:58.897
set your formatting, and
then move on with your merry life, and

361
00:19:58.897 --> 00:20:01.840
it is like you said,
a very easy way to quickly see,

362
00:20:01.840 --> 00:20:06.564
hey I haven't taught that person, or hey,
the duplicates or whatever you want,

363
00:20:06.564 --> 00:20:09.673
that's what conditional
formatting can do for you.

364
00:20:09.673 --> 00:20:11.495
>> Conditional formatting,
all apart of Excel.

365
00:20:11.495 --> 00:20:14.257
That's right,
the Excel 2016 Advanced for Macs.

366
00:20:14.257 --> 00:20:17.265
So Vonne, we do appreciate having
you here in the studios with us,

367
00:20:17.265 --> 00:20:20.166
but it does look like we are coming
to the end of another episode,

368
00:20:20.166 --> 00:20:22.178
because we don't have anymore times left.

369
00:20:22.178 --> 00:20:22.800
[LAUGH] More times?

370
00:20:22.800 --> 00:20:24.886
How about any more minutes
left on that clock.

371
00:20:24.886 --> 00:20:28.078
Signing out for Office Pro TV,
remember I've been your host Wes Bryan.

372
00:20:28.078 --> 00:20:28.866
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

373
00:20:28.866 --> 00:20:31.243
>> And we'll see you next time.

374
00:20:31.243 --> 00:20:35.633
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Vonne explore using outline and subtotals in Excel 2016. Here you will learn how to work with outlines to create collapsible groups of rows and columns to show/hide your data as well as add calculated subtotals to properly sorted ranges.
episodes.title: Outline and Subtotals
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.037 --> 00:00:14.961
Hello to all our TV viewers,
thank you for tuning in to OfficeProTV.

3
00:00:14.961 --> 00:00:16.801
I'm your show host, Wes Bryan.

4
00:00:16.801 --> 00:00:20.870
And in today's episode we're actually
continuing through our series in Excel.

5
00:00:20.870 --> 00:00:23.700
That's right,
it's the Excel 2016 advance for Mac.

6
00:00:23.700 --> 00:00:25.860
And joining us back in
the studio is Miss Vonne Smith.

7
00:00:25.860 --> 00:00:28.060
Vonn, how are we doing today?
>> I'm doing great, how are you?

8
00:00:28.060 --> 00:00:29.260
>> I am doing great,

9
00:00:29.260 --> 00:00:32.640
looking forward to some of the content
that we have in store for us today.

10
00:00:32.640 --> 00:00:34.030
And if my show notes are right,

11
00:00:34.030 --> 00:00:36.560
we're gonna be looking at something
known as outlines and subtotals.

12
00:00:36.560 --> 00:00:39.440
But we're gonna have to let Vonne
tell you what that's about.

13
00:00:39.440 --> 00:00:40.940
>> Well you know what, you are correct.

14
00:00:40.940 --> 00:00:42.760
We are doing outlines and subtotals.

15
00:00:42.760 --> 00:00:46.160
It's funny cuz I'm like, he doesn't
remember what the episode's about,

16
00:00:46.160 --> 00:00:48.418
I wonder if he's gonna throw it back to
me, or is he gonna look at the notes?

17
00:00:48.418 --> 00:00:49.013
>> That's right.

18
00:00:49.013 --> 00:00:51.180
>> [LAUGH] Which way is Wes gonna go?

19
00:00:51.180 --> 00:00:52.630
So good job.
>> Thank you.

20
00:00:52.630 --> 00:00:53.637
>> So it's like you've done this once or

21
00:00:53.637 --> 00:00:55.480
twice?
>> Once or twice.

22
00:00:55.480 --> 00:00:56.310
>> [LAUGH] All right,

23
00:00:56.310 --> 00:01:00.310
so yeah, we are gonna be doing
outlining and subtotals.

24
00:01:00.310 --> 00:01:01.530
What is an outline?

25
00:01:01.530 --> 00:01:04.790
Think back to when you're writing a paper,
in school.

26
00:01:04.790 --> 00:01:07.150
You had to turn in the outline first,
right?

27
00:01:07.150 --> 00:01:11.640
It's just your top level bullet points
of what you're going to be doing.

28
00:01:11.640 --> 00:01:12.350
Right?

29
00:01:12.350 --> 00:01:15.400
Well, that's pretty much what
you're going to be doing in Excel.

30
00:01:15.400 --> 00:01:21.750
You're going to be outlining and creating
collapsible and expandable groups.

31
00:01:21.750 --> 00:01:26.430
So, outlining is going to
be under the Data tab and

32
00:01:26.430 --> 00:01:29.990
it's going to actually be in
the command called Group.

33
00:01:29.990 --> 00:01:33.700
So just in case you're like I don't see
the outline button, yeah, it's grouping.

34
00:01:33.700 --> 00:01:35.230
But that's what we're going to do.

35
00:01:36.580 --> 00:01:39.860
Subtotals is probably one of
my favorite things in Excel.

36
00:01:39.860 --> 00:01:44.470
I love them and hopefully I will
pass on that love to you so

37
00:01:44.470 --> 00:01:46.980
you can think they're pretty cool, too.

38
00:01:46.980 --> 00:01:48.370
So, well let's get started.

39
00:01:48.370 --> 00:01:51.800
I have a file called Outline and
Subtotals.

40
00:01:51.800 --> 00:01:53.920
I wonder where I get these names from.

41
00:01:53.920 --> 00:01:57.480
All right, so
I've got some information here.

42
00:01:57.480 --> 00:02:00.350
Now we're going to be
doing a manual outline.

43
00:02:00.350 --> 00:02:01.780
So right here I've got some information.

44
00:02:01.780 --> 00:02:07.270
We've got the Graphics department, and
I have the Web and Sales Departments.

45
00:02:07.270 --> 00:02:11.830
So now each one of them we've got the same
type of information, first, last.

46
00:02:11.830 --> 00:02:13.710
Notice we have a couple groups in here.

47
00:02:13.710 --> 00:02:17.820
We have the Social Media people,
and then we have the Design people.

48
00:02:17.820 --> 00:02:21.820
And then we also have within the Web and
Sales, we have Developers, and

49
00:02:21.820 --> 00:02:22.930
we have Sales.

50
00:02:24.320 --> 00:02:26.770
Now, when I'm looking at all of this,
this is fine.

51
00:02:26.770 --> 00:02:29.030
I don't have that many rows going on.

52
00:02:29.030 --> 00:02:31.842
But, if you have this times 1,000,

53
00:02:31.842 --> 00:02:37.090
you might not want to really see
the graphics people right now.

54
00:02:37.090 --> 00:02:39.390
And I really just wanna see the web and
sales.

55
00:02:39.390 --> 00:02:44.350
It's a way that you can, it's not hiding,
it's not like we're actually cutting into

56
00:02:44.350 --> 00:02:49.470
here, and hiding our rows,
but we're gonna group them.

57
00:02:49.470 --> 00:02:55.030
So then we can collapse it down to
where we don't really need to see them.

58
00:02:55.030 --> 00:02:59.160
So it's kind of like my favorite saying,
it's kind of the same but

59
00:02:59.160 --> 00:03:00.040
totally different.

60
00:03:00.040 --> 00:03:03.090
So, let's go ahead and
show you how to do it.

61
00:03:03.090 --> 00:03:06.680
You're going to need to first
of all go to your Data tab.

62
00:03:06.680 --> 00:03:09.620
And that's right over here,
see it doesn't say outline.

63
00:03:09.620 --> 00:03:12.628
It says Group,
that's the wrong button [LAUGH] and

64
00:03:12.628 --> 00:03:15.720
then if you drop this
down notice it has Group.

65
00:03:15.720 --> 00:03:17.680
And then at the bottom
we have auto outline,

66
00:03:17.680 --> 00:03:19.060
I'll show you that in another example.

67
00:03:19.060 --> 00:03:23.800
So the first thing you're gonna need
to do is what do I want to group by?

68
00:03:23.800 --> 00:03:29.430
I want all of this,
the graphics to be one group.

69
00:03:29.430 --> 00:03:33.050
So I'm going to select
rows four through 15.

70
00:03:33.050 --> 00:03:34.520
All I did is was just click, hold and

71
00:03:34.520 --> 00:03:39.670
drag down the black arrow pointing
to the right to select my rows.

72
00:03:39.670 --> 00:03:41.880
This needs to become one group.

73
00:03:43.070 --> 00:03:47.250
Select, go to group and you click Group.

74
00:03:47.250 --> 00:03:49.690
Notice over here some
things that are happening.

75
00:03:49.690 --> 00:03:53.900
They're tiny but it becomes almost
like a whole separate area within

76
00:03:53.900 --> 00:03:58.350
your environment, and it has these tiny
little buttons up here for ones and twos.

77
00:03:58.350 --> 00:04:04.080
So this is just like your levels of your
outline or when you make a bulleted list.

78
00:04:04.080 --> 00:04:08.100
When you have sub-bullets or
nested lists inside of them.

79
00:04:08.100 --> 00:04:10.560
That's what we've got going on here.

80
00:04:10.560 --> 00:04:15.220
And what I've done is I've
made a collapsible section.

81
00:04:15.220 --> 00:04:20.127
Notice that if I click that little minus
button right here, it collapses it down,

82
00:04:20.127 --> 00:04:23.060
click that little plus
it expands back out.

83
00:04:23.060 --> 00:04:24.400
That's pretty cool.

84
00:04:24.400 --> 00:04:30.950
So it's grouping your rows into
collapsible and expandable sections.

85
00:04:30.950 --> 00:04:36.260
The ones and the twos are just other
ways that we can click on the one,

86
00:04:36.260 --> 00:04:39.330
and do you see how it's
showing my first level.

87
00:04:39.330 --> 00:04:43.024
Click on the two,
it's gonna show me my second level.

88
00:04:43.024 --> 00:04:44.240
Pretty neat.

89
00:04:44.240 --> 00:04:45.690
Okay, let's keep on doing it.

90
00:04:45.690 --> 00:04:49.320
Let's go ahead and make the Web and
Sales, we'll make that their own group.

91
00:04:49.320 --> 00:04:55.850
I'm choosing the header, or the subheader,
if you want to call it, row.

92
00:04:55.850 --> 00:04:59.750
You can totally select the Web and
Sales and go down through here,

93
00:04:59.750 --> 00:05:03.420
it just depends on how you want
it to look in the different

94
00:05:03.420 --> 00:05:05.980
levels of where they expand and collapse.

95
00:05:05.980 --> 00:05:10.210
So I'm gonna keep like the main heading,
and

96
00:05:10.210 --> 00:05:15.540
then make the next part,
the subheadings, the next group.

97
00:05:15.540 --> 00:05:18.170
So if I go ahead and select that,
you go ahead and click Group.

98
00:05:18.170 --> 00:05:21.365
But notice, it didn't make
a number three over here, did it?

99
00:05:21.365 --> 00:05:25.460
No, because it's on the same level.

100
00:05:25.460 --> 00:05:28.680
I grouped these rows together, and
then I grouped those rows together.

101
00:05:28.680 --> 00:05:33.620
They're all on that level
two of our outline.

102
00:05:33.620 --> 00:05:37.500
So if I click one, here let me zoom out so
you can see this, and scroll up.

103
00:05:37.500 --> 00:05:42.130
Number one is where all of
our levels are collapsed.

104
00:05:42.130 --> 00:05:45.350
Level two is where everything at this

105
00:05:45.350 --> 00:05:49.320
point is expanded to the level two
cuz it's the only few levels I have.

106
00:05:49.320 --> 00:05:52.300
Pretty me, pretty cool.

107
00:05:52.300 --> 00:05:53.450
Let's keep on going.

108
00:05:53.450 --> 00:05:54.720
Let's go over here.

109
00:05:54.720 --> 00:06:01.410
I want to then make a whole
other level of the social media.

110
00:06:01.410 --> 00:06:04.690
I wanna be able to expand and
collapse those guys.

111
00:06:04.690 --> 00:06:08.200
So I select it and then I click Group.

112
00:06:08.200 --> 00:06:11.160
And so
now you could see I've got a level three.

113
00:06:11.160 --> 00:06:15.200
So I could collapse the social media and
then just see design.

114
00:06:15.200 --> 00:06:17.850
Expand the social media and
now I see that.

115
00:06:18.860 --> 00:06:22.870
If I go to level two or to level one,
notice that's where we can go.

116
00:06:22.870 --> 00:06:25.860
So you have to think about
groups within groups.

117
00:06:25.860 --> 00:06:29.020
This is one that gets me, because I'm
thinking I wanna go ahead and make

118
00:06:29.020 --> 00:06:34.420
the design, another group, but look, it's
the same thing we did with the other one.

119
00:06:34.420 --> 00:06:38.462
If I select these and
then go ahead and make this a group,

120
00:06:38.462 --> 00:06:44.499
I'm actually doing some weird things, and
see I've clicked it quite a few times.

121
00:06:44.499 --> 00:06:49.030
I've just made a whole bunch of hidden
levels, which is really strange.

122
00:06:49.030 --> 00:06:55.400
Cuz remember, you have to think about
we were at 1, then we were at 2.

123
00:06:55.400 --> 00:07:01.100
When I go to now 3, 4,
5, they're all the same.

124
00:07:01.100 --> 00:07:04.848
Because remember, Social Media,
once I'm at level 2,

125
00:07:04.848 --> 00:07:10.060
Social media, and
Design are the same level.

126
00:07:10.060 --> 00:07:15.604
So you can't make, it's do you
know what I'm trying to say Wes?

127
00:07:15.604 --> 00:07:17.930
It's kind of hard to verbalize.

128
00:07:17.930 --> 00:07:21.050
Cuz people are like, I wanna make
a social media's expandable, and

129
00:07:21.050 --> 00:07:22.610
design is expandable.

130
00:07:22.610 --> 00:07:24.220
That's not kinda how it works.

131
00:07:24.220 --> 00:07:26.730
It's like this within this,
within this, within this, within this.

132
00:07:26.730 --> 00:07:29.390
So it's kinda like pieces
like nesting dolls, okay.

133
00:07:29.390 --> 00:07:32.890
So otherwise you're at the same level and
if you click them too many times,

134
00:07:32.890 --> 00:07:37.880
you've just got yourself into a really
weird kinda conundrum cause you're like,

135
00:07:37.880 --> 00:07:38.840
wait, where am I?

136
00:07:38.840 --> 00:07:40.900
I thought I'm on level six.

137
00:07:40.900 --> 00:07:42.466
No, you're not.

138
00:07:42.466 --> 00:07:45.440
So be careful about overclicking it.

139
00:07:45.440 --> 00:07:50.450
And overdoing the grouping.

140
00:07:50.450 --> 00:07:53.453
You've got to nest them
inside of each other.

141
00:07:53.453 --> 00:07:57.790
that is another one I'm like, hmm, I've
kind of got myself a little out of whack.

142
00:07:57.790 --> 00:08:01.320
How can I reset myself?

143
00:08:01.320 --> 00:08:03.835
If you come back over here,
we'll actually ungroup.

144
00:08:03.835 --> 00:08:08.167
So if I go ahead and say I wanna go
ahead and clear the outline, well,

145
00:08:08.167 --> 00:08:10.450
it's only clearing the one level.

146
00:08:10.450 --> 00:08:11.920
So what I would suggest doing,

147
00:08:11.920 --> 00:08:16.090
if you wanna get rid of all of your
outlines, I've kinda messed this up, okay?

148
00:08:16.090 --> 00:08:21.070
You go ahead and select the whole
worksheet and then you clear the outline.

149
00:08:21.070 --> 00:08:24.180
And watch what's gonna happen
over here on the left-hand side.

150
00:08:24.180 --> 00:08:28.126
If I clear it, then everything goes away,
I've cleared them all.

151
00:08:28.126 --> 00:08:33.555
Because all I'm doing is just different
ways of organizing my information for

152
00:08:33.555 --> 00:08:35.950
how I want to be able to see it.

153
00:08:35.950 --> 00:08:38.400
Making those collapsible and
expandable groups, okay.

154
00:08:38.400 --> 00:08:41.070
And by the way,
once you clear your outline,

155
00:08:41.070 --> 00:08:45.540
you can't undo, you cannot get

ahead and select these three rows and

383
00:20:56.570 --> 00:20:59.100
then I'm gonna go ahead and,
you said pink, right?

384
00:20:59.100 --> 00:21:02.650
So let's go ahead and
get in some more cell colors.

385
00:21:02.650 --> 00:21:05.130
We're gonna, that's some pink!
>> Boy, that's some pink.

386
00:21:05.130 --> 00:21:07.290
I was almost gonna make the joke
that I think it's salmon.

387
00:21:07.290 --> 00:21:08.810
But no, that's pink.
>> [LAUGH] It's

388
00:21:08.810 --> 00:21:11.850
almost the color of my shirt right now,
yeah, so that's great.

389
00:21:11.850 --> 00:21:12.780
You're like, yeah, it's perfect.

390
00:21:12.780 --> 00:21:15.440
So you come out here, and
then look at what it just did.

391
00:21:15.440 --> 00:21:19.030
It didn't just do those one rows, did it?
>> No, it did not.

392
00:21:19.030 --> 00:21:20.510
>> It did all of it, yeah.

393
00:21:20.510 --> 00:21:22.580
So it's like, ooh.
>> Well,

394
00:21:22.580 --> 00:21:24.118
you wanted it to stand out.
>> [LAUGH]

395
00:21:24.118 --> 00:21:25.956
>> And it does, I can tell you that,

396
00:21:25.956 --> 00:21:26.821
it stands out.

397
00:21:26.821 --> 00:21:29.220
But not exactly what you
wanted to stand out, right?

398
00:21:29.220 --> 00:21:31.670
>> Exactly, I just wanted those one rows.

399
00:21:31.670 --> 00:21:34.020
So the thing that you just
gotta be a little careful,

400
00:21:34.020 --> 00:21:35.360
I'm I'm just doing an Undo.

401
00:21:35.360 --> 00:21:39.620
Once you get it to the level where you
can see it, yes, these are just hiding,

402
00:21:39.620 --> 00:21:40.760
they're collapsed.

403
00:21:40.760 --> 00:21:45.110
But when you made a selection from here
to here, even look at the numbers.

404
00:21:45.110 --> 00:21:49.890
You selected from row 10 to 29,
and everything in between.

405
00:21:50.900 --> 00:21:53.460
So get it to where you like,
just remember your Control key.

406
00:21:53.460 --> 00:21:54.850
Sorry, not Control, we're in Mac.

407
00:21:54.850 --> 00:21:56.080
Command, okay?

408
00:21:56.080 --> 00:21:59.290
Make one selection, hold your Command key.

409
00:21:59.290 --> 00:22:02.360
Make this selection, make this selection.

410
00:22:02.360 --> 00:22:07.217
So I'm actually making three selections,
non-contiguous ranges of cells,

411
00:22:07.217 --> 00:22:11.020
even though they look they
are right next to each other.

412
00:22:11.020 --> 00:22:16.160
And then, if I apply it, now if I go to
four, okay, see, that's what I need to do.

413
00:22:16.160 --> 00:22:23.100
So you can use your levels to get what you
wanna see, like your little subtotal rows.

414
00:22:23.100 --> 00:22:27.350
But use the Command key to make multiple
selections if you wanna format it

415
00:22:27.350 --> 00:22:27.910
differently.

416
00:22:27.910 --> 00:22:32.180
So that's just something that I've always
kinda realized throughout the years and

417
00:22:32.180 --> 00:22:33.070
like to show people.

418
00:22:33.070 --> 00:22:38.250
Cuz it's like, I like it, but if I
could just change this one part of it.

419
00:22:38.250 --> 00:22:40.020
So that's what I like to do.

420
00:22:40.020 --> 00:22:43.090
I love subtotals,
I think they're really cool.

421
00:22:43.090 --> 00:22:46.700
I don't want any of them on there anymore,
I just want to get rid of them.

422
00:22:47.720 --> 00:22:50.200
Well, if you go back over to data, and

423
00:22:50.200 --> 00:22:54.450
you go to subtotals,
you see where I can just remove all?

424
00:22:55.610 --> 00:22:57.050
Then it removes them all, okay?

425
00:22:57.050 --> 00:22:58.740
So that's an easy way to get rid of it.

426
00:22:58.740 --> 00:23:02.700
So again, not doing too much
crazy manipulation of your data,

427
00:23:02.700 --> 00:23:09.060
you're not adding all these crazy
formulas, you Sort, you do the Change By,

428
00:23:09.060 --> 00:23:12.030
what kind of function, and
what calls you wanted to add to it.

429
00:23:12.030 --> 00:23:14.430
You could have done it for
the Calls and the Sales.

430
00:23:14.430 --> 00:23:17.980
You don't have to choose just one, okay?

431
00:23:17.980 --> 00:23:19.520
So just do it however many times.

432
00:23:19.520 --> 00:23:22.340
And if it messes up, just remove them and
start over and see what happens.

433
00:23:22.340 --> 00:23:25.160
So there you go.
>> Outline on Excel, that's right.

434
00:23:25.160 --> 00:23:28.610
And more specifically,
Excel 2016 advanced for Mac.

435
00:23:28.610 --> 00:23:31.970
Now Vaughn, as always, it does look
like we're coming to the end of another

436
00:23:31.970 --> 00:23:34.530
episode, but before we do, do you have any
final words that maybe you would like to

437
00:23:34.530 --> 00:23:37.132
impart to the viewers?
>> I guess the only last thing on that

438
00:23:37.132 --> 00:23:39.850
subtotals is we were doing
it by department, right, and

439
00:23:39.850 --> 00:23:40.835
then we cleared them out.

440
00:23:40.835 --> 00:23:43.735
Cuz maybe you want to change by last name.

441
00:23:43.735 --> 00:23:45.665
I don't think that makes any sense here.

442
00:23:45.665 --> 00:23:48.745
But you can always just remove them,
then sort

443
00:23:48.745 --> 00:23:53.465
the column that you want that change
by,and then go back and add subtotals.

444
00:23:53.465 --> 00:23:57.495
Again, it's always that sorting
of what you want it to change by.

445
00:23:57.495 --> 00:24:00.715
That's something to just always remember.
>> Outlines and subtotals in Excel.

446
00:24:00.715 --> 00:24:03.925
And more specifically, that's right,
Excel 2016 Advanced for Mac,

447
00:24:03.925 --> 00:24:05.955
that is a great place to wrap this one up,
Vonne.

448
00:24:05.955 --> 00:24:08.230
So what do you say,
we'll go ahead and we'll sign out.

449
00:24:08.230 --> 00:24:10.070
We appreciate having you in the studios.

450
00:24:10.070 --> 00:24:12.740
And as always, we appreciate you,
the viewer, watching.

451
00:24:12.740 --> 00:24:15.460
Remember to check out
the entire OFFICEPRO.TV

452
00:24:15.460 --> 00:24:19.200
library that Vonne's been working so
hard to bring to you viewers.

453
00:24:19.200 --> 00:24:21.370
I've been your show host Wes Bryan.
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

454
00:24:21.370 --> 00:24:23.509
>> And we'll see you next time.

455
00:24:23.509 --> 00:24:28.653
[MUSIC]

episodes.description:
"In this episode, Daniel and Vonne examine working with data formatted as tables in Excel 2016. Here they will cover table formatting options, adding/deleting table rows/columns, adding a total row, removing duplicates, and converting to a range.
"
episodes.title: Tables
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:03.962
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.881 --> 00:00:15.940
All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another great episode of OFFICEPRO.TV.

3
00:00:15.940 --> 00:00:20.169
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, and today's
episode well we are taking a look at

4
00:00:20.169 --> 00:00:22.616
tables inside of our Excel Advanced for
Mac.

5
00:00:22.616 --> 00:00:26.433
And joining me in the studio, you know our
good friend that knows everything there is

6
00:00:26.433 --> 00:00:29.980
to know about this lovely little program
our good friend, Miss Vonne Smith.

7
00:00:29.980 --> 00:00:32.430
Vonne we're glad to have you yet
again, how goes it today?

8
00:00:32.430 --> 00:00:35.601
It's going good, everything, eh,
that might be stretching it.

9
00:00:35.601 --> 00:00:39.451
[LAUGH] Listen I'm trying to
increase your methos like build.

10
00:00:39.451 --> 00:00:40.307
My methos what?

11
00:00:40.307 --> 00:00:41.990
Yeah Is that my world?

12
00:00:41.990 --> 00:00:46.095
Yeah you're like a Greek
goddess of Excel knowledge.

13
00:00:46.095 --> 00:00:47.970
Gosh, I think we need to
just stop right here.

14
00:00:47.970 --> 00:00:49.010
So don't mess up?

15
00:00:49.010 --> 00:00:51.730
Yeah no pressure you're
already throwing out words.

16
00:00:51.730 --> 00:00:53.080
She's like is it hot in here?

17
00:00:53.080 --> 00:00:54.690
It seems hot.

18
00:00:54.690 --> 00:00:58.011
[LAUGH] I know you're throwing out
vocabulary that I'm like, what's that?

19
00:00:58.011 --> 00:01:04.640
[LAUGH] But a vocabulary word in Excel
that I do know a lot about is tables.

20
00:01:04.640 --> 00:01:08.690
I love me some tables in Excel,
I use them all the time.

21
00:01:08.690 --> 00:01:13.110
I think they are fantastic and I hope
you will find them just as fantastic as

22
00:01:13.110 --> 00:01:17.280
I do after this episode because,
well, they're pretty cool.

23
00:01:17.280 --> 00:01:21.090
So, I have a file ready to go cuz it's
probably the easiest way to explain it

24
00:01:21.090 --> 00:01:22.800
than to demonstrate it.

25
00:01:22.800 --> 00:01:24.100
So why don't we jump on down.

26
00:01:24.100 --> 00:01:27.250
We have a file named tables,
we got some worksheets going on in here.

27
00:01:27.250 --> 00:01:31.175
And right now these,
a few of these are tables.

28
00:01:31.175 --> 00:01:34.105
And that's kind of a weird thing
because if I was just saying

29
00:01:34.105 --> 00:01:37.945
not within Excel world,
what would you say is, what is a table?

30
00:01:37.945 --> 00:01:38.995
What is a table made of?

31
00:01:38.995 --> 00:01:41.755
A table is made up of,
like cross reference data.

32
00:01:41.755 --> 00:01:43.600
Cross-reference data.

33
00:01:43.600 --> 00:01:45.282
I was going for just rows and columns.

34
00:01:45.282 --> 00:01:47.644
[LAUGH] Well, yeah,
I guess that's what's happening.

35
00:01:47.644 --> 00:01:49.423
[SOUND] And there's the data.

36
00:01:49.423 --> 00:01:50.110
Exactly.

37
00:01:50.110 --> 00:01:51.760
And you're like, well, this is Excel,

38
00:01:51.760 --> 00:01:55.130
a worksheet is just nothing but
rows and columns.

39
00:01:55.130 --> 00:01:55.810
That's true.

40
00:01:55.810 --> 00:01:59.160
So, how is a table any
different than a worksheet?

41
00:01:59.160 --> 00:02:04.220
Well, it is something specific that
they use in Excel, that is saying that

42
00:02:04.220 --> 00:02:10.420
this is a special group or range of
cells that is formatted as a table.

43
00:02:10.420 --> 00:02:15.020
So you're carving out a certain
set of rows and cells to say,

44
00:02:15.020 --> 00:02:19.490
this little demarked area is the table and
not necessarily just random data?

45
00:02:19.490 --> 00:02:21.340
Correct, and it's special and

46
00:02:21.340 --> 00:02:25.950
it has some special features that allows
you to do things with that particular

47
00:02:25.950 --> 00:02:30.720
formatted type of data range that
is different than a worksheet.

48
00:02:30.720 --> 00:02:33.470
Just stuff on a page, if you wanna say.

49
00:02:33.470 --> 00:02:36.580
So yes,
it's a very good definition of that.

50
00:02:36.580 --> 00:02:40.071
So right here,
this one right here is a table,

51
00:02:40.071 --> 00:02:45.633
now how do I know that cells A1 through
D9, how do I know that's a table?

52
00:02:45.633 --> 00:02:51.030
There's a few very key indicators
that I can point out right here.

53
00:02:51.030 --> 00:02:52.250
It's kind of tiny, but

54
00:02:52.250 --> 00:02:55.840
there's this kind of corner
looking thing down at the bottom.

55
00:02:55.840 --> 00:02:57.060
When you see that,

56
00:02:57.060 --> 00:03:02.710
that is indicating that this is
the bottom corner of this table in Excel.

57
00:03:02.710 --> 00:03:05.860
The other thing that I know this is
a table is these little drop downs.

58
00:03:05.860 --> 00:03:07.840
Now these little things
we've seen these before.

59
00:03:07.840 --> 00:03:10.960
We've did this in the filter,
where we did the sort and filter.

60
00:03:10.960 --> 00:03:13.680
Turn on the filters and
you go ahead put those little drop downs.

61
00:03:13.680 --> 00:03:18.740
So you're like, well that's, I wanna
say that's always the be all end all,

62
00:03:18.740 --> 00:03:19.870
this is a table.

63
00:03:19.870 --> 00:03:24.820
This could be just filters that's not as a
table, it's a little weird in there, okay?

64
00:03:24.820 --> 00:03:27.110
[LAUGH] But
those are two things that I can look at.

65
00:03:27.110 --> 00:03:32.910
The other thing that I find that I would
know that it's a table is the formatting.

66
00:03:32.910 --> 00:03:37.760
Do you see how we have the, I want
to say variated, alternating colors,

67
00:03:37.760 --> 00:03:44.130
within our rows, and we have a nice pink
outline, and this is a darker border.

68
00:03:44.130 --> 00:03:45.610
All of this formatting,

69
00:03:45.610 --> 00:03:49.350
this is a big indicator to me that
this is formatted as a table.

70
00:03:49.350 --> 00:03:51.830
Could you go ahead and
format that individually?

71
00:03:51.830 --> 00:03:56.230
Yeah, but it would take a lot of time, cuz
you'd have to select individual cells and

72
00:03:56.230 --> 00:03:57.580
alternating rows, no.

73
00:03:57.580 --> 00:04:01.750
The other biggest thing that
I know that this is a table,

74
00:04:01.750 --> 00:04:06.490
if I click in any one of these
cells we get this little guy.

75
00:04:06.490 --> 00:04:07.930
I'm gonna test your knowledge there,
Daniel,

76
00:04:07.930 --> 00:04:11.230
since you're throwing out stuff like
mythos and ethos at me, I'm like, what?

77
00:04:11.230 --> 00:04:15.130
[LAUGH] Do you know what this little
thing is referred to up in our ribbon?

78
00:04:15.130 --> 00:04:16.110
This particular tab.

79
00:04:16.110 --> 00:04:17.645
I like to call them tabs.

80
00:04:17.645 --> 00:04:20.820
[LAUGH] It's a special tab, though.

81
00:04:20.820 --> 00:04:22.840
It's a format tab.

82
00:04:22.840 --> 00:04:23.720
It's a contextual tab.

83
00:04:23.720 --> 00:04:26.160
There we go, she's trying!

84
00:04:26.160 --> 00:04:29.700
It's a tab that only shows
up when it's needed.

85
00:04:29.700 --> 00:04:32.230
Cuz if I were to click off
into this regular cell,

86
00:04:32.230 --> 00:04:33.680
notice there is- It goes away.

87
00:04:33.680 --> 00:04:34.540
Exactly!

88
00:04:34.540 --> 00:04:40.480
Click in it, brings up the contextual
tab to say that hey, this is a table.

89
00:04:40.480 --> 00:04:41.630
I like the little animation, too.

90
00:04:41.630 --> 00:04:43.310
It just kinda pops up, hi, I'm here.

91
00:04:43.310 --> 00:04:44.077
Yep.
Then it goes away.

92
00:04:44.077 --> 00:04:44.943
[LAUGH] Hi, yeah.

93
00:04:44.943 --> 00:04:49.930
[LAUGH] So that's the biggest thing
that you could do, is click in there.

94
00:04:49.930 --> 00:04:53.690
If that contextual tab comes up,
you definitely know it's in a table.

95
00:04:53.690 --> 00:04:57.560
All right, but for example, this one,
yep, I got that little corner.

96
00:04:57.560 --> 00:05:00.260
That corner's probably one
of the bigger ones, too.

97
00:05:00.260 --> 00:05:02.370
Then if I look over here
on this particular cells,

98
00:05:02.370 --> 00:05:05.970
this looks like it you know its
got the- It's very table like.

99
00:05:05.970 --> 00:05:06.950
Right, Yeah.

100
00:05:06.950 --> 00:05:07.730
Very much so.

101
00:05:07.730 --> 00:05:09.620
But if I click on the cells.

102
00:05:09.620 --> 00:05:11.250
And there's no little corner thingy.

103
00:05:11.250 --> 00:05:15.260
No corner thingy, there's no dropdown
thingies, and there's no contextual tab.

104
00:05:15.260 --> 00:05:16.202
It's a poser.

105
00:05:16.202 --> 00:05:21.180
[LAUGH] [LAUGH] Exactly right, so this was
a table and I actually converted it into

106
00:05:21.180 --> 00:05:23.350
a normal range but
we'll talk about that in a second.

107
00:05:23.350 --> 00:05:28.000
So just kind of identifying that
what do you need to look for

108
00:05:28.000 --> 00:05:29.570
when you have these tables?

109
00:05:29.570 --> 00:05:33.632
And the cool thing about with these tables
is you can have the drop downs like we

110
00:05:33.632 --> 00:05:35.331
have with our regular filters.

111
00:05:35.331 --> 00:05:40.880
Okay, that's nothing new or fancy,
because they're just filters, all right?

112
00:05:40.880 --> 00:05:45.810
But the formatting up here, some of
the options that you have are really cool.

113
00:05:45.810 --> 00:05:48.930
One of them,
since I like to do things in colors,

114
00:05:48.930 --> 00:05:50.680
it's right here with all of our styles.

115
00:05:50.680 --> 00:05:57.300
I can quickly apply a style,
say like this one, and boom, there you go.

116
00:05:57.300 --> 00:05:59.820
Went ahead and changed the font,
it changed the colors of the rows,

117
00:05:59.820 --> 00:06:01.700
we have the alternating colors.

118
00:06:01.700 --> 00:06:04.740
That would take forever if
you were doing this manually.

119
00:06:04.740 --> 00:06:09.690
And don't dismiss the stylistic approach
as something that's just mere fun, right.

120
00:06:09.690 --> 00:06:13.679
Really can help visually see
the entire picture for what it is.

121
00:06:13.679 --> 00:06:16.415
You know that green is this area,
blue is that area,

122
00:06:16.415 --> 00:06:19.025
and color coding things
can really be helpful when

123
00:06:19.025 --> 00:06:22.930
you're trying to quickly jump to
a section in your Excel spreadsheet.

124
00:06:22.930 --> 00:06:27.250
Yeah, and especially when you're reading
down, having those alternating row colors,

125
00:06:27.250 --> 00:06:28.390
it really helps your eye.

126
00:06:28.390 --> 00:06:28.950
Breaks it up.

127
00:06:28.950 --> 00:06:30.340
Rather than taking a piece of paper and

128
00:06:30.340 --> 00:06:31.890
putting it up against
your computer monitor.

129
00:06:31.890 --> 00:06:33.010
That is annoying.

130
00:06:33.010 --> 00:06:34.219
Yeah, I've done it.

131
00:06:34.219 --> 00:06:34.736
I have too.

132
00:06:34.736 --> 00:06:35.266
Yeah, exactly.

133
00:06:35.266 --> 00:06:37.433
Because your eyes Recently.

134
00:06:37.433 --> 00:06:38.810
And your eye jumps.

135
00:06:38.810 --> 00:06:42.781
So having that color coordinating
fill of your rows is much easier

136
00:06:42.781 --> 00:06:47.272
to follow the information than if you
just it as regular formatted cells.

137
00:06:47.272 --> 00:06:50.630
So, that's pretty cool, I like them.

138
00:06:50.630 --> 00:06:54.210
Some other things you
should know about tables.

139
00:06:54.210 --> 00:06:58.650
They are, each one of these are acting
independently from each other.

140
00:06:58.650 --> 00:07:03.550
Now when you start getting multiple
tables within the same rows,

141
00:07:03.550 --> 00:07:05.340
this can get a little weird.

142
00:07:05.340 --> 00:07:06.550
So let me show you what I mean.

143
00:07:06.550 --> 00:07:10.631
Because I've had a lot of experience
over the years of watching

144
00:07:10.631 --> 00:07:12.330
people work with tables.

145
00:07:12.330 --> 00:07:15.380
So it's like, hey,
I wanna put in a new row.

146
00:07:15.380 --> 00:07:18.230
Right, you just come over here and
you insert a row right.

147
00:07:18.230 --> 00:07:22.820
If I was down here in regular cell land,
and I wanted to insert a row above it.

148
00:07:22.820 --> 00:07:27.710
I right click on the row reference and
I go with insert and it inserts a row.

149
00:07:27.710 --> 00:07:32.560
Totally fine, but that's different
when you start working within a table.

150
00:07:32.560 --> 00:07:36.890
If I wanted to add a row
within this table and not kind

151
00:07:36.890 --> 00:07:41.590
of effect some of the other things,
then you don't come over here, all right?

152
00:07:41.590 --> 00:07:44.810
You don't wanna go over to the row that,

showing us how to work with
Goal Seek inside of Excel.

394
00:19:14.875 --> 00:19:17.325
But it looks like that's gonna
call it a day for this episode.

395
00:19:17.325 --> 00:19:19.535
We do thank you out there for
watching as always.

396
00:19:19.535 --> 00:19:23.747
For OfficeProTV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

397
00:19:23.747 --> 00:19:27.318
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

398
00:19:27.318 --> 00:19:32.076
>> And we'll see you next time.

episodes.description: Vonne and Daniel discuss how to remove duplicate data in three different ways:  using the remove duplicate command, conditional formatting, and advanced filters.
episodes.title: Remove Duplicates

But it's actually where you don't

62
00:02:21.814 --> 00:02:23.170
Turn them to duplicates.

63
00:02:23.170 --> 00:02:24.600
But it's still the same commands.

64
00:02:24.600 --> 00:02:25.716

65

Really quickly for those that may

68
00:02:30.910 --> 00:02:32.376

69

>> Got you, so you see two and

00:02:35.297 --> 00:02:38.980

there should only be one.

72
00:02:38.980 --> 00:02:40.181
That's a duplicate we wanna get rid of it.

73

let's say we have a mailing list, right?

74
00:02:44.030 --> 00:02:49.022
I do not want to have a duplicate

75
00:02:49.022 --> 00:02:53.672

same zip, cuz I don't want that.

76
00:02:53.672 --> 00:02:54.910
And it happens, right?

77
00:02:54.910 --> 00:02:58.049
>> It does.
>> Or maybe I can not have duplicate order

78
00:02:58.049 --> 00:02:59.090

79
00:02:59.090 --> 00:03:02.010
>> There's just no way that
we're allowed to have that.

80
00:03:02.010 --> 00:03:04.520
So I need to make sure that I can

81
00:03:04.520 --> 00:03:09.008

based on certain criteria that I set.

82
00:03:09.008 --> 00:03:13.900
And then well, do whatever I want
with it whether I want to remove it,

83
00:03:13.900 --> 00:03:16.030
which would mean remove duplicates.

84
00:03:16.030 --> 00:03:18.310
Or maybe I just wanna highlight it.

85
00:03:18.310 --> 00:03:20.630
I just wanna see the duplicates,
and that's-

86
00:03:20.630 --> 00:03:22.090
>> Get a little glance?

87
00:03:22.090 --> 00:03:25.845
>> Yeah, exactly, give me some type
of formatting that's gonna say hey,

88
00:03:25.845 --> 00:03:27.271

89
00:03:27.271 --> 00:03:30.840
That's where we can do the second way,

90
00:03:30.840 --> 00:03:32.310
And that's just a showing.

91
00:03:32.310 --> 00:03:34.250
It's not actually removing.

92
00:03:34.250 --> 00:03:36.921
And then the last way we're going

94
00:03:38.543 --> 00:03:41.277
which is something we haven't done
in this particular series yet.

95
00:03:41.277 --> 00:03:44.130
So those are the ways
we're gonna go about it.

96

So why don't we get this party started and

Let's go to the file

Alrighty, so

00:04:15.350 --> 00:04:18.938

See in rows 5, 6 and 7, Seva?

>> Yeah, well, I was looking at Sasha and

00:04:26.623 --> 00:04:27.462
I saw a seven.

So I kinda blended them together.

00:04:29.090 --> 00:04:29.993
>> So it's two.

112

>> Yeah.
>> So we're lucky we didn't get Sheva.

113
00:04:32.126 --> 00:04:33.509
>> [LAUGH]
>> Right?

114
00:04:33.509 --> 00:04:35.508
So we got here, Mr. Sasha Kent.

00:04:35.508 --> 00:04:37.300
He's in here three times.

00:04:37.300 --> 00:04:38.640
Sasha was one of my first kitties.

>> Aww.
>> Yes, he was a Russian Blue.

That's why he lives in-

>> That's what I have right now, yeah.

>> Yeah, she's a great cat.

00:04:45.300 --> 00:04:49.351
>> Yes, so that's why he lives at

00:04:49.351 --> 00:04:50.155

00:04:50.155 --> 00:04:54.149

00:04:54.149 --> 00:04:56.600

>> What crazy cat do you have, woman?

00:04:56.600 --> 00:04:59.515

Now, we never heard-

I want to remove the duplicates.

Again, if you've watched the tables

Now, I have put my cursor somewhere

So as soon as I click on

it's going to select that

Okay, so now this is a weird one.

[LAUGH] I think I found a bug.

Do you see how it says my

>> Okay, well, and then it says column A,

00:06:08.270 --> 00:06:11.200
It's like no, those are headers.

00:06:11.200 --> 00:06:13.320

>> Good question.

153
00:06:14.540 --> 00:06:18.518
>> I don't know, okay?
>> I guess, column A would be first.

154
00:06:18.518 --> 00:06:20.920
>> First, yes.
Okay, so I'm thinking all right,

00:06:20.920 --> 00:06:23.240

156
00:06:23.240 --> 00:06:24.020
So I checked it.

157
00:06:24.020 --> 00:06:25.080
Watch, if I go over to Home.

00:06:25.080 --> 00:06:27.133
Remember, we did that our sorting filters.

00:06:27.133 --> 00:06:30.030
You weren't on that episode,

00:06:30.030 --> 00:06:31.580
There's our column names.

161
00:06:31.580 --> 00:06:34.960
So in the sorting filters,
it was doing fine.

162
00:06:34.960 --> 00:06:35.462
Everything was fine.

163
00:06:35.462 --> 00:06:38.050
If I format this as a table, right?

164
00:06:38.050 --> 00:06:39.450
Even if I go and format this is a table.

00:06:39.450 --> 00:06:41.055
Yeah, I have headers.

166
00:06:41.055 --> 00:06:42.920
Yep, okay, we're cool, right?

167
00:06:42.920 --> 00:06:46.801
And in the table tab,
we also have removed duplicates, but

168
00:06:46.801 --> 00:06:49.760
it's still picking out column A, column B.

169
00:06:49.760 --> 00:06:50.950
I don't know.

170
00:06:50.950 --> 00:06:54.210
>> [LAUGH]
>> I did my Office updates.

171
00:06:54.210 --> 00:06:57.310
I'm on the latest update,
which actually fixed.

172
00:06:57.310 --> 00:06:58.607
Remember in the Goal Seek episode,
that weird-

173
00:06:58.607 --> 00:07:00.340
>> Yeah, the Dropbox problem?

174
00:07:00.340 --> 00:07:02.150
>> Yeah, it's fixed for right now.

175
00:07:02.150 --> 00:07:02.810
>> For now.

176
00:07:02.810 --> 00:07:05.890
>> Okay,
I have no clue why this is doing it, okay?

177
00:07:06.900 --> 00:07:09.540
This doesn't do it on the PC version.

178
00:07:09.540 --> 00:07:11.430
Maybe my Mac is just having a bad day.

179
00:07:11.430 --> 00:07:12.010
>> Could be.

180
00:07:12.010 --> 00:07:13.250
>> I don't know.
So for

181
00:07:13.250 --> 00:07:18.400
now, you're just gonna have to live
with it being column A and column B,

182
00:07:18.400 --> 00:07:22.870
because I don't know other
reason why it is doing it.

183
00:07:22.870 --> 00:07:24.589
Maybe yours is doing it just fine.

184
00:07:24.589 --> 00:07:25.910
Roll with it, okay?

185
00:07:25.910 --> 00:07:31.376
So we're going to pretend that my list
headers are showing, A, B, you know.

186
00:07:31.376 --> 00:07:34.030
First, last, department,
and everything like that.

187
00:07:34.030 --> 00:07:37.233
So you're just gonna choose
what criteria you want

188
00:07:37.233 --> 00:07:40.445
the duplicates to meet if
I have them all selected.

189
00:07:40.445 --> 00:07:48.782
That means, every single column has to
be the same for the multiple records.

190
00:07:48.782 --> 00:07:52.695
So the one with the Sasha cat,
with sales and phone number.

191
00:07:52.695 --> 00:07:56.766
That means, every single one has to match.

192
00:07:56.766 --> 00:07:58.666
As opposed to pumpkin.

193
00:07:58.666 --> 00:08:03.690
There might be two pumpkin squashes but
they're in different departments.

194
00:08:03.690 --> 00:08:06.540
Well if they're in different departments
then that's not gonna meet the duplicate

195
00:08:06.540 --> 00:08:09.090
criteria so it won't remove them.

196
00:08:09.090 --> 00:08:12.230
And other key word there, remove.

197
00:08:12.230 --> 00:08:16.960
It is going to search and take them out.

198
00:08:16.960 --> 00:08:20.600
You don't have any other things besides,

199
00:08:20.600 --> 00:08:23.510
when I click okay it just
says hey I found them.

200
00:08:23.510 --> 00:08:25.500
There was four duplicate values.

201
00:08:25.500 --> 00:08:30.500
I removed them which means you
have 22 unique values remaining.

202
00:08:30.500 --> 00:08:32.770
Cool, okay, and then that's where it is.

203
00:08:32.770 --> 00:08:38.240
So it just does it for you, if you're like
I don't wanna see anything beforehand, you

204
00:08:38.240 --> 00:08:42.460
do the work Excel, find me the duplicates
and then go ahead and get rid of them.

205
00:08:42.460 --> 00:08:48.160
Cool, all right, I just had to say
goodbye and not even think of it.

206
00:08:48.160 --> 00:08:52.260
So that is something that you can do, you
don't have to form it as a table first.

207
00:08:52.260 --> 00:08:56.800
And just for examples that we talked about
with unique students versus enrollments

208
00:08:56.800 --> 00:08:58.550
in that table episode.

209
00:08:58.550 --> 00:09:01.310
If you wanted to go ahead and
say, all right,

210
00:09:01.310 --> 00:09:06.220
I want to remove if it has first and
last name, but not the course,

211
00:09:06.220 --> 00:09:09.580
because that would mean I would have,
I believe there's 26.

212
00:09:09.580 --> 00:09:14.010
There's 26, yep the count is 26,
enrollments, but

213
00:09:14.010 --> 00:09:15.600
I need the unique students.

214
00:09:15.600 --> 00:09:19.480
So this is one where I would click
somewhere in my range, go ahead and

215
00:09:19.480 --> 00:09:20.710

216
00:09:20.710 --> 00:09:24.300
Oops, you know what,
I only had two cells selected, so

217
00:09:24.300 --> 00:09:26.730
it's asking me to go ahead and
expand the selection.

218
00:09:26.730 --> 00:09:29.380
Which is what I want to go ahead and do.

219
00:09:29.380 --> 00:09:32.990
So honestly, let's just cancel that,
click there and there we go.

220
00:09:34.020 --> 00:09:36.180
Still not pulling up column headers,
not sure.

221
00:09:36.180 --> 00:09:39.740
But I know that I do not
want the course to match.

222
00:09:39.740 --> 00:09:42.060
So I'm going to say,
as long as their first and

223
00:09:42.060 --> 00:09:46.290
last name are the same,
go ahead and remove them.

224
00:09:46.290 --> 00:09:52.010
So Jack is enrolled in three courses,
but he is only one student,

225
00:09:52.010 --> 00:09:56.710
so if I click okay, again it's removing
it, it found the duplicate values,

226
00:09:56.710 --> 00:10:02.090
removed those out, and
gave me 15 unique values remaining.

227
00:10:02.090 --> 00:10:07.550
Cool, so again, it doesn't have to be all
of them, you set the column criterias

228
00:10:07.550 --> 00:10:11.760
for what is a duplicate or not.

593
00:28:11.534 --> 00:28:13.357
>> [LAUGH] From the X-Files or something,

594
00:28:13.357 --> 00:28:14.796
that's crazy.
>> [LAUGH]

595
00:28:14.796 --> 00:28:16.775
>> But it is cool that this was not just

596
00:28:16.775 --> 00:28:21.300
other filters, this really did seem like
a more advanced way to do filtering.

597
00:28:21.300 --> 00:28:24.080
So I will give you that, Vonne,
it was advanced filters, and

598
00:28:24.080 --> 00:28:25.460
we have you to thank.

599
00:28:25.460 --> 00:28:27.195
And you were delightful so
thank you for joining us, as always.

600
00:28:27.195 --> 00:28:27.781
>> Thanks [LAUGH].

601
00:28:27.781 --> 00:28:29.269
>> And thank you good folks out there,

602
00:28:29.269 --> 00:28:30.515
you were delightful as well.

603
00:28:30.515 --> 00:28:33.075
And I hope you enjoyed this episode,
but we are out of time, so

604
00:28:33.075 --> 00:28:34.550
we're going to call it quits.

605
00:28:34.550 --> 00:28:37.030
Signing off for OFFICEPRO.TV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

606
00:28:37.030 --> 00:28:37.820
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

607
00:28:37.820 --> 00:28:38.661
>> We'll see you next time.

608
00:28:40.990 --> 00:28:43.934
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne look at inserting and formatting shapes in Excel 2016. They demonstrate how to manipulate shapes by resizing, rotating, filling with gradients/colors, connecting shapes with lines, adding text, and editing points.
episodes.title: Shapes: Add and Format
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.550 --> 00:00:15.467
Greetings, everyone, and welcome back to
another exciting episode of OfficeProTV.

3
00:00:15.467 --> 00:00:17.333
I'm your host, Justin Dennison, and

4
00:00:17.333 --> 00:00:20.925
we're coming back at you with
more Excel 2016 Advanced for Mac.

5
00:00:20.925 --> 00:00:25.740
And, well, we're gonna be talking about
shapes, adding them and formatting them.

6
00:00:25.740 --> 00:00:29.658
Luckily, we have our very own shapes
sorceress in the studio today,

7
00:00:29.658 --> 00:00:30.330
Ms. Vonne Smith.

8
00:00:30.330 --> 00:00:31.180
How you doing today, Vonne?

9
00:00:31.180 --> 00:00:32.268
>> I'm a sorceress?

10
00:00:32.268 --> 00:00:34.774
>> You are.
You're just like, pow, look at that.

11
00:00:34.774 --> 00:00:35.931
>> I'm thinking sauces.

12
00:00:35.931 --> 00:00:38.341
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Not a [INAUDIBLE]

13
00:00:38.341 --> 00:00:40.435
>> [LAUGH]

14
00:00:40.435 --> 00:00:42.528
>> Like boom, it works.

15
00:00:42.528 --> 00:00:43.237
>> Like a sorcerer?

16
00:00:43.237 --> 00:00:46.566
>> Yeah, yeah, but a sorceress.

17
00:00:46.566 --> 00:00:48.169
I don't have an accent, all right?

18
00:00:48.169 --> 00:00:49.050
We're just gonna go with it.

19
00:00:49.050 --> 00:00:51.144
>> [LAUGH] I was like,
I am getting kinda hungry.

20
00:00:51.144 --> 00:00:52.402
I'd love some sauce right now.

21
00:00:52.402 --> 00:00:54.098
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

22
00:00:54.098 --> 00:00:54.714
>> But yes,

23
00:00:54.714 --> 00:00:56.874
we are going to move on to shapes.

24
00:00:56.874 --> 00:00:59.536
They are part of our graphical elements,
and

25
00:00:59.536 --> 00:01:02.771
we're going to be [LAUGH]
adding them formatting them.

26
00:01:02.771 --> 00:01:04.370
I know it's crazy, right?

27
00:01:04.370 --> 00:01:08.141
So little bit different
than working with images.

28
00:01:08.141 --> 00:01:11.010
It's the same but different,
my favorite saying.

29
00:01:11.010 --> 00:01:13.561
So let's just go ahead and
get back into it.

30
00:01:13.561 --> 00:01:17.779
I'm used the same file that
I left off on last episode.

31
00:01:17.779 --> 00:01:22.669
And you were saying, Justin, that Bishop
is kinda scaring you right now, right?

32
00:01:22.669 --> 00:01:23.716
>> I didn't say he was scary.

33
00:01:23.716 --> 00:01:26.323
I said he was absolutetly terrifying.

34
00:01:26.323 --> 00:01:27.185
I dont know.

35
00:01:27.185 --> 00:01:29.949
He's like jackaloupe cat or
something or cat rapture.

36
00:01:29.949 --> 00:01:30.920
I don't know.

37
00:01:30.920 --> 00:01:31.422
It's weird, though.

38
00:01:31.422 --> 00:01:33.380
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, he's a little scary.

39
00:01:33.380 --> 00:01:36.590
So you know what, hey, why don't
we just go ahead and there you go?

40
00:01:36.590 --> 00:01:38.090
You feeling better now?

41
00:01:38.090 --> 00:01:39.491
>> I am soothed.

42
00:01:39.491 --> 00:01:40.440
Thank you so much.

43
00:01:40.440 --> 00:01:41.519
>> Awesome.

44
00:01:41.519 --> 00:01:45.913
All right, I'm gonna add another
blank worksheet for now and

45
00:01:45.913 --> 00:01:47.950
use our moving it to the end.

46
00:01:49.280 --> 00:01:52.860
Come on, gotta look for the triangles.

47
00:01:52.860 --> 00:01:57.163
I always tell people that and I'm not
listening to my own rules, all right?

48
00:01:57.163 --> 00:02:01.765
We have our format shape
task pane up right now.

49
00:02:01.765 --> 00:02:03.187
It's like magical cuz it's shaped,

50
00:02:03.187 --> 00:02:06.015
no, it's just cuz there's nothing
in there right now, okay?

51
00:02:06.015 --> 00:02:09.386
But same with our images, you could
always go to that particular pane and

52
00:02:09.386 --> 00:02:10.497
do some other editing.

53
00:02:10.497 --> 00:02:13.335
We'll come back to that
a little bit later.

54
00:02:13.335 --> 00:02:14.335
How do I insert a shape?

55
00:02:14.335 --> 00:02:16.880
Well, we go to the Insert tab for
one thing.

56
00:02:16.880 --> 00:02:21.160
And then, we go to Shape, and there's
all sorts of cool little shapes in here.

57
00:02:21.160 --> 00:02:23.340
Let's just start with a pretty basic one.

58
00:02:23.340 --> 00:02:24.840
We'll go with a circle.

59
00:02:24.840 --> 00:02:26.150
So it's just like a box of crayons.

60
00:02:26.150 --> 00:02:28.920
You're picking out the crayon
that you would like to draw with.

61
00:02:28.920 --> 00:02:31.860
So when I click it, people are like,
well, there's no circle.

62
00:02:31.860 --> 00:02:34.650
I know, it's kinda like when you
pick a crayon out of the box,

63
00:02:34.650 --> 00:02:36.270
the crayon's in your hand.

64
00:02:36.270 --> 00:02:40.530
And then once you have the crayon in your
hand, you have to draw onto the paper.

65
00:02:40.530 --> 00:02:41.728
So that's what you have to do.

66
00:02:41.728 --> 00:02:46.810
It's loaded up and notice that my cursor
looks like a crosshair right now.

67
00:02:46.810 --> 00:02:49.350
So that means I can do one of two things.

68
00:02:49.350 --> 00:02:54.340
I can click once or
I can click, hold, and drag.

69
00:02:54.340 --> 00:02:59.880
If I single click, it will go ahead and
insert that shape.

70
00:02:59.880 --> 00:03:04.853
It took a little while, and
it puts it into how that shape is

71
00:03:04.853 --> 00:03:09.231
normally shaped, [LAUGH] for
lack of a better term.

72
00:03:09.231 --> 00:03:11.480
It's a perfect circle right now.

73
00:03:11.480 --> 00:03:15.882
Notice I'm back into like my
regular Excel cell selection now,

74
00:03:15.882 --> 00:03:18.829
I do not have the crayon
in my hand anymore.

75
00:03:18.829 --> 00:03:19.779
I'm not drawing.

76
00:03:19.779 --> 00:03:23.723
So if I wanted go back and
draw another circle, go back to Insert,

77
00:03:23.723 --> 00:03:26.060
go back to Shapes, pick a circle.

78
00:03:26.060 --> 00:03:29.160
So let's do the other way of inserting
a shape, you do the click, hold, and drag.

79
00:03:29.160 --> 00:03:33.700
When I click, hold, and drag, notice
I can make this more of like an oval,

80
00:03:33.700 --> 00:03:36.140
whether long or tall.

81
00:03:36.140 --> 00:03:38.000
I'm just holding my mouse down and

82
00:03:38.000 --> 00:03:42.930
when I let go,
it will make that particular shape.

83
00:03:42.930 --> 00:03:45.470
So you have the option
of kinda free-forming

84
00:03:45.470 --> 00:03:47.340
in how you want that
particular shape to be.

85
00:03:48.950 --> 00:03:51.060
And it's free form.

86
00:03:51.060 --> 00:03:54.780
But if I went back over here to Insert and
we go back into Shapes and

87
00:03:54.780 --> 00:03:58.410
let's say we go with,
let's take a heart right here.

88
00:03:58.410 --> 00:03:59.160
If I click, hold and

89
00:03:59.160 --> 00:04:03.840
drag and I'm not holding any keys, notice
I can make it kinda long, kind of wide.

90
00:04:03.840 --> 00:04:08.160
But if I wanted to keep it in
the proportions that the shape was

91
00:04:08.160 --> 00:04:12.780
meant to be in, I have not let go of my
mouse right now, that's why I can do this.

92
00:04:12.780 --> 00:04:16.150
If I hold my Shift key,
the Shift key will maintain proportions.

93
00:04:16.150 --> 00:04:18.190
We talked about that in
one of the other episodes.

94
00:04:18.190 --> 00:04:20.890
And it's just the same thing
that we do with all graphics.

95
00:04:20.890 --> 00:04:23.520
Shift to maintain proportion.

96
00:04:23.520 --> 00:04:27.331
So if I let go of the mouse first,
and then let go of the Shift key,

97
00:04:27.331 --> 00:04:30.098
now I can make that heart
whatever size I want.

98
00:04:30.098 --> 00:04:34.094
But just like with our pictures,
if you wanted to resize this circle,

99
00:04:34.094 --> 00:04:36.814
notice I get my four point arrows,
I select it.

100
00:04:36.814 --> 00:04:39.088
Get the corner, make this bigger.

101
00:04:39.088 --> 00:04:42.037
If I wanted to hold this Shift
key here while I size it,

102
00:04:42.037 --> 00:04:43.953
that's something to know about.

103
00:04:43.953 --> 00:04:48.444
So the Shift is going to be important when
we're working with shapes as opposed to

104
00:04:48.444 --> 00:04:48.981
images.

105
00:04:48.981 --> 00:04:50.990
Remember with images,
we could've gotten the corner and

106
00:04:50.990 --> 00:04:53.650
it would've maintained
proportions automatically.

107
00:04:53.650 --> 00:04:55.600
Doesn't work like that with shapes.

108
00:04:55.600 --> 00:04:59.885
Gotta hold that Shift key down
to go ahead and make that,

109
00:04:59.885 --> 00:05:02.444
I wanted to make it bigger there.

110
00:05:02.444 --> 00:05:04.399
So that's what you need to know about.

111
00:05:04.399 --> 00:05:05.630
You still have the rotate.

112
00:05:05.630 --> 00:05:10.350
So if I want to rotate this heart
a little bit more, that's wonderful.

113
00:05:10.350 --> 00:05:15.290
Cuz maybe I wanna put this here, and
then I might as well go ahead and

114
00:05:15.290 --> 00:05:17.862
do this now just because I want to.

115
00:05:17.862 --> 00:05:20.180
I want to copy this.

116
00:05:20.180 --> 00:05:22.530
Now, just with anything,
you could copy and paste.

117
00:05:22.530 --> 00:05:23.310
Totally fine.

118
00:05:23.310 --> 00:05:24.530
I could have this selected.

119
00:05:24.530 --> 00:05:31.510
I could Cmd+C, Cmd+B, and then I have
another one or I'm gonna delete this.

120
00:05:31.510 --> 00:05:35.227
Either way,
if I want to duplicate by dragging,

121
00:05:35.227 --> 00:05:37.867
you can use your Alt key or Option.

122
00:05:37.867 --> 00:05:42.033
Alt+Option and
then drag will make a duplicate.

123
00:05:42.033 --> 00:05:46.037
As opposed to in PC land,
I believe it's Ctrl.

124
00:05:46.037 --> 00:05:49.576
But Alt with all of my
graphic editing programs,

125
00:05:49.576 --> 00:05:53.474
it's always Alt to duplicate so
that's [INAUDIBLE].

126
00:05:53.474 --> 00:05:56.255
So maybe I wanna go ahead and
then rotate this over here.

127
00:05:56.255 --> 00:06:02.450
Cuz I don't know, I'm making this weird
heart, antelope looking thing right now.

128
00:06:02.450 --> 00:06:05.970
Not really sure what I'm doing, but hey,
I'm just making shapes and I'm having fun.

129
00:06:05.970 --> 00:06:07.930
So those are the different
things that you can go ahead and

130
00:06:07.930 --> 00:06:11.750
rotate, duplicate,
now let's go ahead and format.

131
00:06:11.750 --> 00:06:15.115
I wanna make this a different color.

132
00:06:15.115 --> 00:06:19.327
Have it selected, now notice at
the top just like your images,

133
00:06:19.327 --> 00:06:22.034
you have a shape format contextual tab.

134
00:06:22.034 --> 00:06:26.555
With shapes you have insides and
you have outsides, fills, or

135
00:06:26.555 --> 00:06:30.580
I wanna say strokes, but
here they call them outlines.

136
00:06:30.580 --> 00:06:35.300
If I wanted to change the inside
color of this, I could.

137
00:06:35.300 --> 00:06:37.158
Maybe I wanna make it green.

138
00:06:37.158 --> 00:06:42.200
Maybe I wanna make it some other
fill color like this light purple.

139
00:06:43.660 --> 00:06:44.620
Go like that.

140
00:06:44.620 --> 00:06:49.600
The other thing you can do with your
fills is that you can use gradients.

141
00:06:49.600 --> 00:06:51.476
You could also use textures.

142
00:06:51.476 --> 00:06:53.410
You gotta have some dead fish textures.

143
00:06:53.410 --> 00:06:54.950
I just love this one.

144
00:06:54.950 --> 00:06:55.706
Yeah, no.

145
00:06:55.706 --> 00:06:58.210
We're gonna go ahead and
do the [INAUDIBLE].

146
00:06:58.210 --> 00:06:59.405
You can also do a picture.

147
00:06:59.405 --> 00:07:03.604
But the thing is I will tell you is
remember the cropping that we did,

148
00:07:03.604 --> 00:07:07.593
that's way easier that filling
the shape in with that picture.

149
00:07:07.593 --> 00:07:10.724
And it also distorts it and
everything like that, but

150
00:07:10.724 --> 00:07:12.331
you do have it as an option.

151
00:07:12.331 --> 00:07:15.663
I'm just gonna go ahead and
choose this pink color right here.

152
00:07:15.663 --> 00:07:17.021
And with the gradients,

153
00:07:17.021 --> 00:07:20.974
notice how it's only doing this
particular color that I have right now.

154
00:07:20.974 --> 00:07:25.846
And then so like black, or pink to white,
you want more gradients and

155
00:07:25.846 --> 00:07:29.044
pink and blue and
purple and green, you can.

156
00:07:29.044 --> 00:07:31.413
It's just in the format
pictures task pane.

157
00:07:31.413 --> 00:07:35.461
I wanna save that just for a little
bit later cuz you can also do that on

158
00:07:35.461 --> 00:07:39.315
outlines, which are not available
directly in this dropdown.

159
00:07:39.315 --> 00:07:44.030
But it is in the format shape task pane.

160
00:07:44.030 --> 00:07:45.860
So we've got our fill.

161
00:07:45.860 --> 00:07:47.170
We have our outline.

162
00:07:47.170 --> 00:07:50.690
And maybe I will make this
a light pink outline.

163
00:07:50.690 --> 00:07:52.519
I can make this thicker.

164
00:07:52.519 --> 00:07:54.602
These are things that
we did in our images.

165
00:07:54.602 --> 00:07:57.230
Can't really see that, so
why don't I go with blue?

166
00:07:57.230 --> 00:07:58.920
That makes it a little bit better.

167
00:07:58.920 --> 00:08:02.706
And just like images,
you have all the same effects.

168
00:08:02.706 --> 00:08:07.951
You cam do glows, you can do beveled,
you can do 3D rotations.

169
00:08:07.951 --> 00:08:09.510
You just basically, go through and pick.

170
00:08:09.510 --> 00:08:16.063
That really didn't do much for me,
so lets go with a green glow, cute.

171
00:08:16.063 --> 00:08:16.920
Oopps, sorry,
that's a little bit too much.

172
00:08:16.920 --> 00:08:18.321
You can pick all those.

173
00:08:18.321 --> 00:08:22.691
You have some presets that are up at the
top that have any combination of shadows,

174
00:08:22.691 --> 00:08:25.660
reflections, glows, edges,
and so on and so forth.

175
00:08:26.780 --> 00:08:33.306
The styles are, they're not as,
I don't know how to say, extensive?

176
00:08:33.306 --> 00:08:34.930
If you wanna say, than the images.

177
00:08:34.930 --> 00:08:40.122
Notice it's just going to do things like,
does it give like a little drop shadow?

178
00:08:40.122 --> 00:08:41.885
Does it give you transparency?

179
00:08:41.885 --> 00:08:47.790
Does, I don't know, I don't usually
use the styles too much on the shapes.

180
00:08:47.790 --> 00:08:52.672
I'll pick them myself through
the effects and the fills and

181
00:08:52.672 --> 00:08:56.180
the outlines, and go from there.

182
00:08:56.180 --> 00:09:00.030
But, notice there's like, why is this
only ABC, why does it have text?

183
00:09:00.030 --> 00:09:02.750
We're talking about shapes, right?

184
00:09:02.750 --> 00:09:06.936
Well that's because you can
add text into your shapes.

185
00:09:06.936 --> 00:09:08.200
That could be kind of fun.

186
00:09:08.200 --> 00:09:12.717
And that's why it's showing you, these
different options of like, what color,

187
00:09:12.717 --> 00:09:14.081
I want to go back to pink.

188
00:09:14.081 --> 00:09:18.220
Of what color your text would be
within the style that you're picking.

189
00:09:18.220 --> 00:09:21.986
So, just in case,
you're wondering about that, that text and

190
00:09:21.986 --> 00:09:24.861
shapes don't match,
actually they do, okay?

191
00:09:24.861 --> 00:09:29.820
But we'll come back to that
in just a minute, okay?

192
00:09:29.820 --> 00:09:33.683
So, I've got these different
little guys here, I don't know,

193
00:09:33.683 --> 00:09:35.310
again, what I'm making.

194
00:09:35.310 --> 00:09:38.435
But, I wanna go back over
to some other things.

195
00:09:38.435 --> 00:09:41.987
Cuz, these right now,
this heart and this circle,

196
00:09:41.987 --> 00:09:46.369
these are what we would call in
a vector program, closed paths.

197
00:09:46.369 --> 00:09:49.260
They have an inside and
they have an outside.

198
00:09:49.260 --> 00:09:55.072
But you also have shapes that are just
lines and notice it says lines.

199
00:09:55.072 --> 00:09:59.770
When I have a line shape, if I just click,
hold, and drag this, okay?

200
00:09:59.770 --> 00:10:03.909
I don't have any fills, I could click it
all day long and it's not gonna work,

201
00:10:03.909 --> 00:10:05.565
cuz there's nothing inside.

202
00:10:05.565 --> 00:10:09.420
The only way that it's going
to apply is with the outline.

203
00:10:09.420 --> 00:10:13.769
So if I choose, say, purple and
then made this a lot thicker,

204
00:10:13.769 --> 00:10:16.040
that's where I get my formats.

205
00:10:16.040 --> 00:10:21.024
You can also add arrows onto lines,
because, maybe I wanted to have

206
00:10:21.024 --> 00:10:25.760
pointed arrows, or little dots
in between or on the ends there.

207
00:10:25.760 --> 00:10:29.339
You go into so many more options
in that arrows over here,

208
00:10:29.339 --> 00:10:31.364
if you drop down behind my head.

209
00:10:31.364 --> 00:10:37.020
You can see we have like the cup type and
joint type and the beginning and endings.

210
00:10:37.020 --> 00:10:39.714
And like, do you want,
how you want your dashes to be.

211
00:10:39.714 --> 00:10:44.410
Compound path, there's a lot
of fun stuffs that you can do.

212
00:10:44.410 --> 00:10:48.610
With any of your shapes, whether it
be lines or circles and squares.

213
00:10:48.610 --> 00:10:53.234
To where you can kinda do a lot more
formatting than just that's available in

214
00:10:53.234 --> 00:10:54.400

00:22:38.410 --> 00:22:40.520
I can make my own gradients.

445
00:22:40.520 --> 00:22:44.290
I can then change the angle
of them if I wanted to.

446
00:22:44.290 --> 00:22:46.356
I can make the direction change.

447
00:22:46.356 --> 00:22:51.472
So you have a lot of fun stuff that you
can do with formatting your gradients and

448
00:22:51.472 --> 00:22:56.610
your shapes, whether you want to do,
notice they have it as a gradient line.

449
00:22:56.610 --> 00:23:00.125
So I could do the same thing for
the outside or

00:23:00.125 --> 00:23:03.530
the stroke outline versus the inside.

451
00:23:03.530 --> 00:23:05.940
You can do that with your text outlines.

452
00:23:05.940 --> 00:23:07.992
So Gradients, I love them.

453
00:23:07.992 --> 00:23:08.792
You know what?

454
00:23:08.792 --> 00:23:10.780
I just like rainbows.

455
00:23:10.780 --> 00:23:11.409
I like lots of colors.

456
00:23:11.409 --> 00:23:17.220
So [LAUGH] I wanna show you guys
that within the format task pane.

00:23:17.220 --> 00:23:21.730
And you can go to it any time you
feel you need a little bit more

00:23:21.730 --> 00:23:23.020
color in your life too.

459
00:23:23.020 --> 00:23:27.200
>> And I think maybe this shouldn't
be said, but I feel compelled,

00:23:27.200 --> 00:23:28.920
cuz I know I struggle with things.

00:23:28.920 --> 00:23:30.820
If the stroke of a line, the outline or

462
00:23:30.820 --> 00:23:35.360
whatever, is not large enough, you may
not actually see much about it, right?

463
00:23:35.360 --> 00:23:39.210
This tiny little what's the smallest,
1.1 or something?

464
00:23:39.210 --> 00:23:40.878
>> I think it's half or something, right?

465
00:23:40.878 --> 00:23:42.423
>> Something which is tiny.

466
00:23:42.423 --> 00:23:43.890
>> A quarter of a point.

467
00:23:43.890 --> 00:23:45.652
>> Yeah, you may not see anything, right?

468
00:23:45.652 --> 00:23:46.443
>> Yeah.
[LAUGH]

469
00:23:46.443 --> 00:23:47.050
>> So typically,

470
00:23:47.050 --> 00:23:49.812
when you're doing gradients or
something special like that adding.

471
00:23:49.812 --> 00:23:53.186
Those are gonna be thicker lines
that you want to accentuate.

472
00:23:53.186 --> 00:23:54.310
And now you can see them.

473
00:23:54.310 --> 00:23:55.817
So it's something to remember.

474
00:23:55.817 --> 00:24:02.470
Now, Vonne, I feel like we've done a lot,
not enough.

00:24:02.470 --> 00:24:05.590
But do we have anything else that we need
to consider when it comes to shapes and

00:24:05.590 --> 00:24:06.850

477
00:24:06.850 --> 00:24:10.000

00:24:10.000 --> 00:24:14.230
So this gets into making

00:24:14.230 --> 00:24:16.520
