480
00:24:16.520 --> 00:24:21.200
By the way, really quick,
you have raster information, pixels.

481
00:24:21.200 --> 00:24:24.820
Your photographs are raster or
bitmap, whatever.

482
00:24:24.820 --> 00:24:25.920
It's just a bunch of pixels.

483
00:24:25.920 --> 00:24:29.680
When you have vector information,
vector does not have any pixels.

484
00:24:29.680 --> 00:24:32.873
It's just lines or points and strokes.

485
00:24:32.873 --> 00:24:36.061
It's all bunch of math, right?

486
00:24:36.061 --> 00:24:40.921
Okay, so this is where and
we're essentially creating vectors,

487
00:24:40.921 --> 00:24:43.451
they are vectors, in the shapes.

488
00:24:43.451 --> 00:24:46.005
But you can manipulate them.

489
00:24:46.005 --> 00:24:47.479
Let me show you.

490
00:24:47.479 --> 00:24:48.532
So we have a square, right?

491
00:24:48.532 --> 00:24:50.715
And let's take this square right here.

492
00:24:50.715 --> 00:24:55.460
Okay, so a square has four sides.

493
00:24:55.460 --> 00:24:58.330
Which means, it has four points.

494
00:24:58.330 --> 00:25:00.990
If I brought in a triangle,

495
00:25:00.990 --> 00:25:04.320
this is bringing me back to
geometry class, love geometry.

496
00:25:04.320 --> 00:25:07.700
So we have this,
then a triangle is three points.

497
00:25:07.700 --> 00:25:11.280
So if I take and do, here,
I'll just take this circle.

498
00:25:11.280 --> 00:25:15.210
I'm just gonna go ahead and copy and
then down here I'm gonna paste.

499
00:25:15.210 --> 00:25:15.730
A circle and

500
00:25:15.730 --> 00:25:20.520
a square are the same in the sense
that they only have four points, okay?

501
00:25:20.520 --> 00:25:22.690
But that's a circle,
that doesn't have any points.

502
00:25:22.690 --> 00:25:29.960
It does, but it has directions and
how that path travels out of that point.

503
00:25:29.960 --> 00:25:35.344
And what you can do in your shapes
is you can come over to this button,

504
00:25:35.344 --> 00:25:37.800
and you can go into Edit the points.

505
00:25:37.800 --> 00:25:42.479
And when I click on this,
notice if I zoom in a little bit.

506
00:25:42.479 --> 00:25:48.230
These points now become where I get this
like kinda little directional handle.

507
00:25:48.230 --> 00:25:51.630
I can manipulate each one
of them individually.

508
00:25:51.630 --> 00:25:54.660
So I can make this more of like a diamond.

509
00:25:54.660 --> 00:25:57.134
But then once you click on the point,
you can move the point.

510
00:25:57.134 --> 00:26:00.110
Do you see these kinda like
white things right here?

511
00:26:00.110 --> 00:26:02.240
These are your Bezier handles.

512
00:26:02.240 --> 00:26:05.590
These are where you can
actually take this and change.

513
00:26:05.590 --> 00:26:10.390
You can change the direction
of how that path travels

514
00:26:10.390 --> 00:26:14.660
out of that point taking
it from a square point.

515
00:26:14.660 --> 00:26:17.350
Or a straight point to a curved point,
okay?

516
00:26:17.350 --> 00:26:19.900
Again, a lot more stuff
with vector information.

517
00:26:19.900 --> 00:26:22.900
You can pull this out, move it in.

518
00:26:22.900 --> 00:26:24.350
And this is just where
you can go ahead and

519
00:26:24.350 --> 00:26:28.915
start making some really
interesting claw like thing.

520
00:26:28.915 --> 00:26:31.530
[LAUGH] I'm thinking like an animal claw.

521
00:26:31.530 --> 00:26:34.100
This is like a cat claw,
like their little toenails.

522
00:26:34.100 --> 00:26:38.596
>> It's funny that you say that, because
I thought it was an upside down recliner.

523
00:26:38.596 --> 00:26:40.890
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

524
00:26:40.890 --> 00:26:43.496
maybe we want different
things in our lives, Vonne.

525
00:26:43.496 --> 00:26:47.189
>> [LAUGH] Is it the blot test that is-
>> Yeah, [LAUGH] Rorschach testing?

526
00:26:47.189 --> 00:26:47.793
>> Yeah.

527
00:26:47.793 --> 00:26:48.940
>> What do you see?

528
00:26:48.940 --> 00:26:49.925
Upside down recliner
>> [LAUGH]

529
00:26:49.925 --> 00:26:51.900
>> I see a cat claw.

530
00:26:51.900 --> 00:26:53.306
All right, well, there you go.

531
00:26:53.306 --> 00:26:56.840
[LAUGH] So yes,
you can change each one of these points.

532
00:26:56.840 --> 00:26:58.900
And that's what your circle is doing.

533
00:26:58.900 --> 00:27:03.080
If I go into the edit points there,
it's just four points, but

534
00:27:03.080 --> 00:27:04.710
they have directions on them.

535
00:27:04.710 --> 00:27:06.300
And that's how you can change it.

536
00:27:06.300 --> 00:27:10.600
So It would be kind of fun to take your
shapes and then make upside down recliners

537
00:27:10.600 --> 00:27:16.100
or cat claws, and take any shape and
manipulate it that way.

538
00:27:16.100 --> 00:27:18.650
The other thing that you'll see
I actually didn't realize it,

539
00:27:18.650 --> 00:27:20.360
they had one on the triangle.

540
00:27:20.360 --> 00:27:22.964
Do you see this yellow dot up at the top?

541
00:27:22.964 --> 00:27:26.914
That yellow dot will come up on
certain shapes, not all of them,

00:27:26.914 --> 00:27:30.880
certain shapes that will allow you
to take it and it will let you.

00:27:32.290 --> 00:27:36.433
Now, we're getting into right
triangles and isosceles and

544
00:27:36.433 --> 00:27:39.960
its perfect scalene triangles,
and all that kinda fun stuff.

545
00:27:39.960 --> 00:27:41.740
So it will allow you to change it.

546
00:27:41.740 --> 00:27:46.480
Let me show you some other shapes
that this will come up on.

00:27:46.480 --> 00:27:49.720
Let's go over here to the sun, okay?

00:27:49.720 --> 00:27:51.970
So if I, ooh, sorry, take the sun.

00:27:51.970 --> 00:27:55.220
Notice there's a little yellow dot here.

00:27:55.220 --> 00:27:59.150
It's where I can make the rays longer or

551
00:27:59.150 --> 00:28:02.000
So there's some different
ways that you can

00:28:02.000 --> 00:28:06.553

00:28:06.553 --> 00:28:09.430
I guess, that's a square, isn't it?

Turn that frown [SOUND] upside down,

00:28:30.019 --> 00:28:30.659
>> I don't know, but

00:28:30.659 --> 00:28:32.925
I'm getting real nervous,

00:28:32.925 --> 00:28:34.900

>> So I've heard that saying.

00:28:40.100 --> 00:28:45.780

00:28:45.780 --> 00:28:47.330

00:28:47.330 --> 00:28:51.323

00:28:53.536 --> 00:28:56.880
You can format them, you can add text.

This is another one.

The thing is here you would have

Especially, if I needed

All right, just remember, you have to

00:30:28.290 --> 00:30:33.420
But you still have the same options

00:30:33.420 --> 00:30:36.080

00:30:37.110 --> 00:30:41.215

00:30:41.215 --> 00:30:43.890

607
00:30:43.890 --> 00:30:47.230

00:30:47.230 --> 00:30:50.760

00:31:08.040 --> 00:31:09.340

00:31:09.340 --> 00:31:10.870

00:31:10.870 --> 00:31:13.700

00:31:13.700 --> 00:31:14.670

00:31:14.670 --> 00:31:15.610

620
00:31:15.610 --> 00:31:18.049

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne show you how to add a pictures to your Excel 2016 spreadsheets. Here they will demonstrate inserting images from a file or Photos app, as well as resizing, rotating, and moving images. They also demonstrate how to use the format picture task pane as well as insert a screenshot and screen clipping.
episodes.title: Images: Basics

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne dive deeper into working with graphics inside of Excel 2016. Here they will show you how to format images by adding borders, effects, styles, image corrections, and artistic effects. They also show how to reset pictures, change pictures, and compress images. Finally, they demonstrate the remove background command and add alternate text titles and descriptions for accessibility.

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne continue working with graphics in Excel 2016. Here you will see how to select multiple shapes, duplicate, rotate, align, change stacking order, group/ungroup, and use the selection pane.

00:18:58.943 --> 00:18:59.970
I don't know.

350
00:19:01.520 --> 00:19:07.570
Bringing back the Selection Pane,
or the Format Pane really.

351
00:19:07.570 --> 00:19:08.790
That's not what I want, I'm sorry.

352
00:19:08.790 --> 00:19:12.430
I said the Selection Pane,
which would be this one, there you go.

353
00:19:12.430 --> 00:19:14.590
Okay, and
actually now I have two panes open.

354
00:19:14.590 --> 00:19:19.680
Notice I had the Format Shape task
pane and the Select task pane, cool.

355
00:19:19.680 --> 00:19:21.390
I know it's a group cuz
it says it right there.

356
00:19:21.390 --> 00:19:24.750
There's Group 9, okay.

357
00:19:24.750 --> 00:19:29.840
So this is a good way to see
if you have grouped elements.

358
00:19:29.840 --> 00:19:33.635
The other thing, what if I wanted to
change one of the eyeballs, right?

359
00:19:33.635 --> 00:19:36.820
I wanna just get one of them to be green,
right?

360
00:19:36.820 --> 00:19:39.118
Cuz he just wants a green eye.

361
00:19:39.118 --> 00:19:44.290
If you single-click, or
use the Selection Pane, you can isolate

362
00:19:44.290 --> 00:19:49.670
pieces of a group and
then change just that one.

363
00:19:49.670 --> 00:19:54.115
Because if I had selected
just the whole group and

364
00:19:54.115 --> 00:19:58.571
come into the color, see,
it does both of them.

365
00:19:58.571 --> 00:20:04.000
So it's a nice way to be able to isolate
pieces of a group, know that it's a group,

366
00:20:04.000 --> 00:20:08.310
and then be able to just make
some determinations from there.

367
00:20:08.310 --> 00:20:11.020
You could still go ahead and
do this without the Selection Pane.

368
00:20:11.020 --> 00:20:15.340
If I just single-clicked on one
of the pieces within a group,

369
00:20:15.340 --> 00:20:17.650
you can still isolate that way.

370
00:20:17.650 --> 00:20:19.260
Totally fine.

371
00:20:19.260 --> 00:20:21.460
So now if I wanna go ahead and
get all of these,

372
00:20:21.460 --> 00:20:27.180
I would select on its eyes,
hold the Shift key, get there, get there.

373
00:20:27.180 --> 00:20:29.330
Even better, you know what you can do?

374
00:20:29.330 --> 00:20:33.145
You can use your Shift key
from the Selection Pane,

375
00:20:33.145 --> 00:20:36.610
haha, to select all of your elements.

376
00:20:36.610 --> 00:20:39.953
So especially if you're working
with really small pieces,

377
00:20:39.953 --> 00:20:41.927
like that mouth piece right there.

378
00:20:41.927 --> 00:20:47.730
It's kinda hard to get at because it's
tiny, okay, so use this to your advantage.

379
00:20:47.730 --> 00:20:50.840
So once I have all of this,
I can come up to here.

380
00:20:50.840 --> 00:20:53.650
I can go to Group, and we'll group that.

381
00:20:53.650 --> 00:20:56.290
And notice, there you go,
this is one piece.

382
00:20:56.290 --> 00:21:00.720
So now the whole bunny
travels as one piece.

383
00:21:00.720 --> 00:21:04.270
I have these expandable and
collapsible groups, and so

384
00:21:04.270 --> 00:21:06.850
I have a group within a group.

385
00:21:06.850 --> 00:21:10.150
And then this is one whole piece.

386
00:21:10.150 --> 00:21:14.960
So grouping elements can be very,
very handy, like the sun and the text box.

387
00:21:14.960 --> 00:21:19.743
My bunny, I don't wanna have its
ears being away from its head.

388
00:21:19.743 --> 00:21:21.670
This is starting to get
really gruesome right now.

389
00:21:21.670 --> 00:21:25.340
We need to just keep the bunny intact and
be happy.

390
00:21:25.340 --> 00:21:28.550
Just be careful about when you go
ahead and have a group and you select.

391
00:21:28.550 --> 00:21:32.070
It's like, okay,
see now everything has that same fill.

392
00:21:32.070 --> 00:21:36.060
So if you wanted to
isolate individual pieces,

393
00:21:36.060 --> 00:21:42.060
you do have to select them by
themselves and then go from there.

394
00:21:43.170 --> 00:21:48.140
So if you want to make cute little
bunnies on your Excel spreadsheet,

395
00:21:49.140 --> 00:21:54.090
cuz at the time of this recording,
it's almost, I call it bunny day.

396
00:21:54.090 --> 00:21:55.900
Because I love bunnies,

397
00:21:55.900 --> 00:22:00.200
and so it's all about the bunnies,
at least in my world, so.

398
00:22:00.200 --> 00:22:00.870
>> Well, I will tell you,

399
00:22:00.870 --> 00:22:03.530
Vonne, seeing this little bunny
may make it a little easier

400
00:22:03.530 --> 00:22:07.950
to swallow some of those bad reports that
could also be on that Excel spreadsheet.

401
00:22:07.950 --> 00:22:10.760
You're like, we lost ten grand,
but look at this bunny.

402
00:22:10.760 --> 00:22:14.610
And you go, I do feel better, but
what was that number you said?

403
00:22:14.610 --> 00:22:18.110
So these can be incredibly handy,
and just as we've grouped,

404
00:22:18.110 --> 00:22:21.870
you can also ungroup as you've
seen kind of down below, right?

405
00:22:21.870 --> 00:22:23.470
>> Yes, definitely, and it is fun.

406
00:22:23.470 --> 00:22:26.025
There is one thing that
I wanted to mention.

407
00:22:26.025 --> 00:22:29.220
That I looked at my notes, and
I was like, ooh, just in case.

408
00:22:29.220 --> 00:22:31.870
In case you're coming from a PC world, and

409
00:22:31.870 --> 00:22:37.040
pretty much like the most recent versions
of Excel with whatever update you have.

410
00:22:37.040 --> 00:22:42.300
There's also something in any of your
Office products in Windows called Icons.

411
00:22:42.300 --> 00:22:45.530
Like I said, it's up at the top where
you could actually insert an icon.

412
00:22:45.530 --> 00:22:51.482
And it's almost like, well, they're
almost like emojis, but they're not.

413
00:22:51.482 --> 00:22:55.160
They're like little pieces, and they kind
of look like a bunny, if you want to say.

414
00:22:55.160 --> 00:22:59.099
So it has a piece of paper or
what have you, and

415
00:22:59.099 --> 00:23:02.800
the icons are treated as special shapes.

416
00:23:02.800 --> 00:23:05.020
That's right, there you go,
that's what I was trying to say.

417
00:23:05.020 --> 00:23:07.780
It's a shape that looks like a bunny, or
a shape that looks like a computer screen,

418
00:23:07.780 --> 00:23:09.430
or something like that.

419
00:23:09.430 --> 00:23:12.850
Icons don't exist in Office for Mac.

420
00:23:14.154 --> 00:23:15.270
They're kinda cool, but

421
00:23:15.270 --> 00:23:19.320
unfortunately Mac always gets kind of the
short end of the stick in what it can and

422
00:23:19.320 --> 00:23:23.520
can't support, and so, in case you're
looking for it, they don't exist.

423
00:23:23.520 --> 00:23:29.660
And I did include icons in this
particular episode in the PC show,

424
00:23:29.660 --> 00:23:34.780
so in case you're watching both cuz you
just wanna get all the versions of Excel,

425
00:23:34.780 --> 00:23:36.640
that's what's missing.

426
00:23:36.640 --> 00:23:41.630
>> Well, Vonne that is some, I well tell
you, the Selection Pane, believe it or

427
00:23:41.630 --> 00:23:45.180
not the explanation on that actually
helped me think about layers and

428
00:23:45.180 --> 00:23:47.150
some of these other
things a little better.

429
00:23:47.150 --> 00:23:50.290
I was like, I gotta go do that.

430
00:23:50.290 --> 00:23:53.270
So I'm feeling a little creative,
and after this episode,

431
00:23:53.270 --> 00:23:54.400
you probably do as well, so

432
00:23:54.400 --> 00:23:59.830
go draw something in Excel and, well,
try to hide some of those bad reports.

433
00:23:59.830 --> 00:24:03.620
But we're gonna go ahead and get out of
here because, well, we are done, right?

434
00:24:03.620 --> 00:24:06.480
So signing off for OfficePro.TV,
I've been your host, Justin Dennison.

435
00:24:06.480 --> 00:24:07.350
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

436
00:24:07.350 --> 00:24:09.128
>> And we'll see you next time

437
00:24:09.128 --> 00:24:14.288
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne explore using SmartArt in Excel 2016. Here they will show you how to use SmartArt to more easily add a graphical element to your spreadsheets by giving you self-adjusting themes, text, and shapes.
episodes.title: SmartArt
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.022 --> 00:00:09.056
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.861 --> 00:00:14.109
All right, greetings, everyone, and

3

episode of OFFICEPRO.TV.

4
00:00:17.557 --> 00:00:21.434
I am your host, Mr. Daniel Lowrie, and

5

Well, actually, let me start there,

So now that we're all on the same page,
joining us in the studio, our good friend,

00:00:28.904 --> 00:00:29.747
Ms. Vonne Smith.

00:00:30.770 --> 00:00:32.433

00:00:32.433 --> 00:00:33.201

11
00:00:33.201 --> 00:00:34.655
>> I did, I did, I threw myself off.

12
00:00:34.655 --> 00:00:36.001
>> [LAUGH]
>> It was all that

14
00:00:37.139 --> 00:00:38.830
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

>> [LAUGH] If you're like,

00:00:49.086 --> 00:00:50.615

00:00:52.270 --> 00:00:54.394
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, so as you can tell,

we don't film these exactly in
order every time so, [LAUGH].

23
00:00:58.429 --> 00:00:59.858
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

24
00:00:59.858 --> 00:01:02.384
yes, we went from remove
duplicates to SmartArt [LAUGH].

25
00:01:02.384 --> 00:01:04.210
>> Weird, but hey, [LAUGH].

26
00:01:04.210 --> 00:01:06.819
>> Yeah, that's what we do here,
we have a little bit of fun.

27
00:01:06.819 --> 00:01:09.013
>> In the land of freedom,
you can do whatever you want like that.

28
00:01:09.013 --> 00:01:11.673
>> [LAUGH] We need to shut you down, okay?

29
00:01:11.673 --> 00:01:13.630
[LAUGH] Just concentrate on Excel.

30
00:01:13.630 --> 00:01:14.752
>> That's right.

31
00:01:14.752 --> 00:01:19.598
>> [LAUGH] So SmartArt, we had to remove
duplicates, if you're talking about,

00:01:19.598 --> 00:01:21.545
hey, I've seen this before.

33
00:01:21.545 --> 00:01:24.551
Yeah, because SmartArt
lives in every product.

00:01:24.551 --> 00:01:28.116
So you can do this in PowerPoint,

35
00:01:28.116 --> 00:01:31.066
I think you can even do it in Outlook,
okay?

36
00:01:31.066 --> 00:01:34.441
So, I feel like I've taught this
stuff 1,000 times, [LAUGH].

37
00:01:34.441 --> 00:01:35.253
>> Yeah, [LAUGH].

38
00:01:35.253 --> 00:01:38.265
>> But hey,
it might be brand new to you, and

00:01:38.265 --> 00:01:43.021
that's why I put it in every single
product that we do, because.

40
00:01:43.021 --> 00:01:45.432
>> Because it's in every
single product we use.

41
00:01:45.432 --> 00:01:48.454
>> Exactly, and it's always part

42
00:01:48.454 --> 00:01:51.148
>> Well, the good news is, if you've
seen any of the other episodes for

43
00:01:51.148 --> 00:01:52.224
any of the other products.

44
00:01:52.224 --> 00:01:53.034
That have SmartArt in them,

45
00:01:53.034 --> 00:01:54.596
you're probably going to
be very familiar with this.

46
00:01:54.596 --> 00:01:57.035
>> [LAUGH] Yes, and
you might learn something new.

47
00:01:57.035 --> 00:01:59.883
And maybe you're just here for the good
old Vonne and Daniel show, [LAUGH].

48
00:01:59.883 --> 00:02:04.244
>> [LAUGH] I'm going to stop right there,
[LAUGH].

49
00:02:04.244 --> 00:02:08.060
>> Yes, okay, so, [LAUGH],
what is SmartArt?

50
00:02:08.060 --> 00:02:10.010
>> It has a high IQ.

51
00:02:10.010 --> 00:02:14.763
>> It's art that's smart,
I think I make that joke every time, too.

52
00:02:14.763 --> 00:02:19.547
So it is just a graphical
representation of data.

53
00:02:19.547 --> 00:02:25.377
And it just kind of gives
you a little more pizzaz for

54
00:02:25.377 --> 00:02:31.165
maybe a list or a procedure or
maybe a flow chart.

55
00:02:31.165 --> 00:02:33.597
The orb charts,
that's what I was trying to get to.

56
00:02:33.597 --> 00:02:36.181
This used to be insert charts and
diagrams, and

57
00:02:36.181 --> 00:02:40.393
the diagrams had the organizational
charts and some other things like that.

58
00:02:40.393 --> 00:02:44.800
Well, it's just grown up over the years,
and they made SmartArt, okay?

59
00:02:44.800 --> 00:02:47.938
So that's what we're going to be going
over, and you're like, but this is Excel.

60
00:02:47.938 --> 00:02:50.519
But yeah,
Excel talks about your numbers, and

61
00:02:50.519 --> 00:02:53.946
you might want to be able to have a nice,
quick little graphic.

62
00:02:53.946 --> 00:02:57.365
That might illustrate your
point a little bit better so

63
00:02:57.365 --> 00:02:59.898
that's why we're going to be doing it.

64
00:02:59.898 --> 00:03:02.350
And again, it's in Excel,
so that's why, [LAUGH].

65
00:03:02.350 --> 00:03:04.517
>> [LAUGH] Leave no stone unturned,
right, Vonne?

66
00:03:04.517 --> 00:03:09.139
>> Exactly, it is a graphical element,
and that's what it is, so let's do it.

67
00:03:09.139 --> 00:03:13.977
I have a file,
it's just a blank file, it's Book2,

68
00:03:13.977 --> 00:03:19.672
I had another new file before him,
we're going to go to Insert.

69
00:03:19.672 --> 00:03:23.271
And over here, it is part of our
illustrations because we talked about

70
00:03:23.271 --> 00:03:24.979
inserting pictures and shapes.

71
00:03:24.979 --> 00:03:31.156
And now we get with SmartArt, so we have
all sorts of categories that's SmartArt.

72
00:03:31.156 --> 00:03:36.054
We have Lists, we have Processes, and I
think you get the idea that sometimes you

73
00:03:36.054 --> 00:03:39.310
need to be talking about
a process rather than a list.

74
00:03:39.310 --> 00:03:41.751
You have Relationships and Hierarchies.

75
00:03:41.751 --> 00:03:46.702
And the cool thing is that you get little
graphical representations of each one

76
00:03:46.702 --> 00:03:48.284
of those off to the side.

77
00:03:48.284 --> 00:03:49.773
And then you can pick one,

78
00:03:49.773 --> 00:03:53.723
this is where the gallery is slightly
different than the PC version.

79
00:03:53.723 --> 00:03:57.732
The PC version opens up in a window,
it has a little bit more information,

80
00:03:57.732 --> 00:04:00.984
it's a little bit more colorful,
but we get the idea here.

81
00:04:00.984 --> 00:04:03.677
So if I wanted to add some of our lists,
like, okay,

82
00:04:03.677 --> 00:04:06.143
maybe let's just start
with a super basic one.

83
00:04:06.143 --> 00:04:09.579
We'll start with our basic block list,
okay, cool.

84
00:04:09.579 --> 00:04:15.231
So I just want to show the different
categories that are in our departments or

85
00:04:15.231 --> 00:04:18.161
what have you, I don't know, [LAUGH].

86
00:04:18.161 --> 00:04:22.177
So I get that and let's just talk
about the super basics right now.

87
00:04:22.177 --> 00:04:26.338
It is inserted, one,
it is not anywhere connected to a cell.

88
00:04:26.338 --> 00:04:30.547
Just like all of our graphical elements,
it's kind of floating on top,

89
00:04:30.547 --> 00:04:32.487
if you want to say, that's one.

90
00:04:32.487 --> 00:04:36.712
Two is that we get some contextual tabs.

91
00:04:36.712 --> 00:04:38.383
When we have contextual tabs,

92
00:04:38.383 --> 00:04:41.806
we know if we've added something
in that was not there before.

93
00:04:41.806 --> 00:04:44.083
Just like when we formatted as tables,

94
00:04:44.083 --> 00:04:48.778
the tables contextual tab came up when we
put in pictures or shapes, same thing.

95
00:04:48.778 --> 00:04:53.707
So that's our stuff up here, we can
notice that we have our SmartArt Design

96
00:04:53.707 --> 00:04:56.690
where we see things like layouts and
styles.

97
00:04:56.690 --> 00:05:01.502
Yeah, there we go again, and
then we have a Format tab, and

98
00:05:01.502 --> 00:05:06.239
we have our fills and
our outlines and our word art styles.

99
00:05:06.239 --> 00:05:09.241
Okay, well, this looks really familiar,
oops, sorry, I just collapsed it.

100
00:05:09.241 --> 00:05:12.780
This looks very familiar when we were
doing shapes, yeah, because you know what?

101
00:05:12.780 --> 00:05:17.186
SmartArt is just a collection of shapes,
that's it, okay?

102
00:05:17.186 --> 00:05:22.653
That they went ahead and put together
a templated format to go ahead and

103
00:05:22.653 --> 00:05:26.740
say, this is easier for
you to go ahead and add text.

104
00:05:26.740 --> 00:05:31.454
And act as one element,
and it's a special group.

105
00:05:31.454 --> 00:05:35.548
Because we did talk about grouping
in our arrange and align episode,

106
00:05:35.548 --> 00:05:38.808
that's when we were talking
about multiple objects.

107
00:05:38.808 --> 00:05:42.107
So it is grouped, but
it's a fancy group, okay?

108
00:05:42.107 --> 00:05:47.382
And it has some extra special
things that it can do.

109
00:05:47.382 --> 00:05:49.392
So if I wanted to add in the text,

110
00:05:49.392 --> 00:05:53.353
because that's basically what
we're going to be doing here.

111
00:05:53.353 --> 00:05:57.467
Is putting in some information
into this graphical element,

112
00:05:57.467 --> 00:05:59.772
there is a couple ways we can do it.

113
00:05:59.772 --> 00:06:04.673
Notice over here that this is
our text based way that I could

114
00:06:04.673 --> 00:06:09.288
add in the text, [LAUGH],
in a list, I know it's like.

115
00:06:09.288 --> 00:06:11.962
>> [LAUGH] I love to watch Vonne
just spiral out of control with her

116
00:06:11.962 --> 00:06:12.651
double speak.

117
00:06:12.651 --> 00:06:16.153
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

118
00:06:16.153 --> 00:06:17.400
>> It's all the time, too,

119
00:06:17.400 --> 00:06:19.392
because I start explaining, I'm like.

120
00:06:19.392 --> 00:06:21.907
>> And then she's like,
I'm making no sense to even me, [LAUGH].

121
00:06:21.907 --> 00:06:25.355
>> [LAUGH] It's like,
there is nowhere else I can go besides.

122
00:06:25.355 --> 00:06:28.037
>> We're going to get you a
word-of-the-day calendar to increase your

123
00:06:28.037 --> 00:06:28.894
vocabulary, [LAUGH].

124
00:06:28.894 --> 00:06:33.738
>> [LAUGH] Seriously, but
this is the Text pane of our SmartArt and

125
00:06:33.738 --> 00:06:35.613
it's a different way.

126
00:06:35.613 --> 00:06:38.936
And I know that this is our Text
pane because, one, I can see it.

127
00:06:38.936 --> 00:06:41.672
Two, there's a little button up here for
Text pane, and

128
00:06:41.672 --> 00:06:44.018
there's also this little
triangle right here.

129
00:06:44.018 --> 00:06:48.403
So if you don't see this, by any chance,
if you click this little button,

130
00:06:48.403 --> 00:06:49.457
it collapses in.

So you have to be careful about

Versus taking and

I'm sure there's dedicated software,

>> [LAUGH] I mean, you are preparing for

a specific way,
>> If I wanted to flip this to

So if you need to switch

So let's go back to this one, so I said

It wasnt just regular shapes

And that's why it gives us

This was especially in, sometimes if

I want specific places or

There's ways you can just

there's a shape format,

So if I took this and then,

I just made that bigger,

And then you could do whatever

Cuz maybe you really just wanted

That is SmartArt, art that is smart, and

00:24:31.220 --> 00:24:35.510
>> Well, it does add a little pizzazz,
a little flair to all of our spreadsheets,

00:24:35.510 --> 00:24:36.165

446
00:24:36.165 --> 00:24:38.933
Cuz it could take the mundane and

Especially when you're sitting

Don't discount the ability for

It really will make you go, well, at least

So play with SmartArt,

Like the 1000th time on

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne will explore shared workbooks in Excel 2016. Here they cover the why and how of sharing workbooks as well as showing you what to expect when working with shared workbooks.
episodes.title: Shared Workbooks
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.166 --> 00:00:15.461
Greetings everyone and welcome back to
another exciting episode of OfficeProTv,

3
00:00:15.461 --> 00:00:16.786
I'm your host Justin Dennison.

4
00:00:16.786 --> 00:00:18.305
Well, you've ask for it and so

we're coming back at you with
more Excel 2016 Advance for Mac.

6
00:00:21.655 --> 00:00:24.663
And well we're gonna be
looking at Shared Workbooks.

7
00:00:24.663 --> 00:00:28.081
Workbooks, yeah workbooks, I had to
think I always get those words mixed up.

8
00:00:28.081 --> 00:00:30.819
But luckily we have someone who is not
gonna get them mixed up and take us

9
00:00:30.819 --> 00:00:34.129

Vonne Smith how are you doing today Vonne?

00:00:34.129 --> 00:00:35.656
I'm doing great, I always mix them up.

11
00:00:35.656 --> 00:00:38.381
[LAUGH] Man,
you're not supposed to tell anybody.

I know, but tell everybody like

13
00:00:41.392 --> 00:00:45.495
[LAUGH] It is, right at work, and work,
and you're like, I remember the work part,

00:00:45.495 --> 00:00:47.870
but is it a book, or
a sheet, or I don't know.

15
00:00:47.870 --> 00:00:49.150
Did I come to work today, who knows?

16
00:00:49.150 --> 00:00:50.850
[LAUGH] Where am I, what's my name?

00:00:50.850 --> 00:00:53.505
Yeah, it is Monday for us but
you all don't really know that,

00:00:53.505 --> 00:00:55.103

19

But yes,
we are gonna talk about shared workbooks.

20

Now this is, to me, gonna be
an interesting episode, because recently

21
00:01:04.650 --> 00:01:09.611
at the time of this recording,
which is, we are in April of 2018,

22
00:01:09.611 --> 00:01:14.850
the support files that you have on
Microsoft Help dot com and everything.

23
00:01:14.850 --> 00:01:18.817
They've put a new little
addendum to the page which,

24
00:01:18.817 --> 00:01:24.372
I can almost guarantee the last time
I taught, or recorded this particular

25
00:01:24.372 --> 00:01:30.366
episode in the PC version They didn't have
that, so there has been another shift

26
00:01:30.366 --> 00:01:35.418
in the Microsoft Office world that
they're saying hey guess what?

27
00:01:35.418 --> 00:01:39.050
Shared workbooks,
that's going to be deprecated.

28
00:01:39.050 --> 00:01:41.995
We are going to not use that anymore.

29
00:01:41.995 --> 00:01:44.480
They're actually calling it legacy, now.

30
00:01:44.480 --> 00:01:49.523
They're saying this has been
replaced with coauthoring.

31
00:01:49.523 --> 00:01:52.756
So you shouldn't be doing
shared workbooks anymore.

32
00:01:52.756 --> 00:01:58.790
And I'm like okay, I hear you Microsoft,

33

The thing is,

34

there's a whole bunch of people out
there that still use shared workbooks.

35
00:02:04.084 --> 00:02:08.530
So I think it's gonna take a little
bit of a time to kinda shift off and

36
00:02:08.530 --> 00:02:10.960
not everybody updates all the time.

37
00:02:10.960 --> 00:02:14.383
And yes, Office 365 in all its glory and
the subscription-based models.

38
00:02:14.383 --> 00:02:19.894
And of course, the whole push towards
cloud computing and what they can do now.

39
00:02:19.894 --> 00:02:23.494
But that is fantastic and I think it's
wonderful how they've progressed.

40

But there still gonna be plenty of people
that still work with shared workbooks,

41
00:02:28.102 --> 00:02:30.330
so you need to understand them.

42
00:02:30.330 --> 00:02:34.613
So while Microsoft is deeming this as old,
right now, I don't know,

43
00:02:34.613 --> 00:02:39.349
I don't know if it's that old just yet,
but you know how they like to do that.

44
00:02:39.349 --> 00:02:41.816
Yeah, and
this is kind of the way of the future,

45
00:02:41.816 --> 00:02:44.223
technology is gonna be
changing a great deal,

46

however you used a word that's actually
used as verbage, a deprecation.

47
00:02:48.570 --> 00:02:53.063
Deprecation can mean an indeterminate
time period based on some arbitrary

48

decision about what versions

49
00:02:57.285 --> 00:03:00.170
So, I think it's a worthwhile

50

Now, I'm not privy to any Microsoft

51
00:03:04.141 --> 00:03:08.600
Maybe their deprecation schedule is

52
00:03:08.600 --> 00:03:12.801
Next release, it's out, that's a,
we're taking this away.

53

Deprecation typically means there's a lead
time in order to give people, as you said,

54
00:03:17.763 --> 00:03:19.860
time to transition away.

55
00:03:19.860 --> 00:03:22.414
All the while trying to push
people to say, you know what,

56
00:03:22.414 --> 00:03:24.147
you shouldn't be using this any more.

57
00:03:24.147 --> 00:03:27.160
Use this new niffy because
this is deprecated.

58
00:03:27.160 --> 00:03:30.033
So do keep those things in mind,
still probably need to know,

59
00:03:30.033 --> 00:03:34.086
because there might be legacy systems that
you encounter that still use this feature.

60
00:03:34.086 --> 00:03:37.568
Yeah, and I don't think that this
is one of those ones that they

61
00:03:37.568 --> 00:03:40.670
can ever fully get rid of,
I really don't think so.

62
00:03:40.670 --> 00:03:43.378
But I understand where they're going,

63
00:03:43.378 --> 00:03:47.213
and why don't we talk about
what have we been going with?

64
00:03:47.213 --> 00:03:49.620
What is a shared workbook?

65
00:03:49.620 --> 00:03:52.463
And this is where it starts to
get a little convoluted and

66
00:03:52.463 --> 00:03:53.682
everything like that.

67
00:03:53.682 --> 00:03:59.370
Why don't we come down to my computer,
just so I have some visuals to go with.

68
00:03:59.370 --> 00:04:03.920
So I brought up some web pages
that are in the episode notes.

69
00:04:03.920 --> 00:04:07.553
So let's talk about
shared workbook feature.

70
00:04:07.553 --> 00:04:08.858
And right here,

71
00:04:08.858 --> 00:04:14.500
this is the new little blurb on top
that I know was not here the last time.

72
00:04:14.500 --> 00:04:17.581
So, it's basis,
it's an older feature that allows you to

73
00:04:17.581 --> 00:04:21.663
collaborate on a workbook with multiple
people, that's what it's saying.

74
00:04:21.663 --> 00:04:24.799
It does have a lot of limitations and
that is true,

75
00:04:24.799 --> 00:04:29.440
that's always been the case when
we're working with shared workbooks.

76
00:04:29.440 --> 00:04:33.915
But the idea is that you would
be able to collaborate on

77
00:04:33.915 --> 00:04:36.607
the same with multiple people.

78
00:04:36.607 --> 00:04:40.313
But there's this kinda weird caveat
about it, it's you'd still have to, and

79
00:04:40.313 --> 00:04:41.690
we're talking about.

80

Again, we're talking old school in the
sense cloud computing didn't really exist.

81
00:04:46.415 --> 00:04:51.050
We didn't really have OneDrives and

82
00:04:51.050 --> 00:04:55.683
And all these kind of shared cloud storage
places that's become I think pretty common

83
00:04:55.683 --> 00:04:59.234
place now-a-days, but
you did have networks drives, right.

84
00:04:59.234 --> 00:05:02.995
If you worked in a large organization,
you were all on the network together, so

85
00:05:02.995 --> 00:05:04.860
you could save it up to the share drive.

86
00:05:04.860 --> 00:05:06.676
And maybe it's the U drive,
or the M drive.

87
00:05:06.676 --> 00:05:10.039
And the letter association,
it's just something they pick,

88
00:05:10.039 --> 00:05:12.518
it's usually something
low in the alphabet.

89
00:05:12.518 --> 00:05:17.328
But as long as you guys, you guys meaning
the people that you work with in your

90
00:05:17.328 --> 00:05:20.862
office, could access that
file on that network drive,

91
00:05:20.862 --> 00:05:23.740
then you could work in
this shared workbook.

92
00:05:23.740 --> 00:05:26.785
But this is where I always
feels kinda weird, so

93
00:05:26.785 --> 00:05:29.076
are we kinda shared network drive?

94
00:05:29.076 --> 00:05:33.000
Like, don't you both already
have access to the file?

95
00:05:33.000 --> 00:05:37.372
And you can just open it, right,
I mean- You can probably open it.

96
00:05:37.372 --> 00:05:42.170
And this is is where things, I like to
think of a shared network drive as your

97
00:05:42.170 --> 00:05:46.900
own personal little cloud,
not truly cuz it gets a little iffy.

98
00:05:46.900 --> 00:05:49.725
But I think, and
I could be completely wrong here,

99
00:05:49.725 --> 00:05:54.259
probably whatâ€™s happening is if youâ€™re
designating this is a shared workbook,

100
00:05:54.259 --> 00:05:58.398
behind the scenes the application is
making sure that, like you say you and

101
00:05:58.398 --> 00:06:01.580
I are both editing,
right whose edit remains upon save?

102
00:06:01.580 --> 00:06:04.702
Is it the last edit,
is it based on role permissions?

103
00:06:04.702 --> 00:06:08.227
It's trying to make sure you donâ€™t
have this conflicting, if you and

104
00:06:08.227 --> 00:06:10.572
I both change like an invoice number,
right.

105
00:06:10.572 --> 00:06:14.540
And we change it to something different,
does mine persist or does yours persist?

106
00:06:14.540 --> 00:06:18.050
They are on shared drive, but
how do we make sure we have integrity of

107
00:06:18.050 --> 00:06:21.144
the document based on
candidate's editing permissions?

108
00:06:21.144 --> 00:06:22.856
That does a great point, yeah.

109
00:06:22.856 --> 00:06:28.207
Cuz I could go ahead and
have a non shared through Excel Workbook.

110
00:06:28.207 --> 00:06:32.382
You and I can open it, and
I made changes, you made changes but

111
00:06:32.382 --> 00:06:35.540
we had no idea who did what, when, right?

112
00:06:35.540 --> 00:06:39.743
And that's the biggest part
of why you'd want to actually

113
00:06:39.743 --> 00:06:43.185
designate a workbook
through excel as shared.

114
00:06:43.185 --> 00:06:46.709
Because there is a cool thing that

productivity workflow

However, it looks like they're just kinda,

So you should definitely have

>> [LAUGH]
>> No, no, I jest, but track changes,

I have to call them,

I'm sorry let me close the workbook, and

that's the only way that I

It happens,

But you will get this

It happened, so you will have to

So that's a fun one too.

[LAUGH]
>> Well Vonne,

00:23:45.685 --> 00:23:48.758
Keep our data from getting corrupted and

415
00:23:48.758 --> 00:23:49.948
It's just trying to keep you safe.

416
00:23:49.948 --> 00:23:51.928
Though annoying,
it's trying to keep you safe.

417
00:23:51.928 --> 00:23:52.595
And Vonne,

But we still got to talk

As we continue to explore

So definitely come on back.

425
00:24:09.516 --> 00:24:11.092

00:24:11.092 --> 00:24:13.802

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne dive into track changes in Excel 2016. Here they will explain why you would want to enable tracking and how to accomplish that. They also take you through the tracking process to help you understand how this may benefit you in your working environment.
episodes.title: Track Changes

put the blame on someone else than me.

>> Yes, [LAUGH] Or if it is me,

Track changes is not

Where I use a lot,

And see I did the whole like

It's like, come on.

So if it shows you and the examples

episodes.description: Justin and Vonne show how to collaborate in real-time with co-authoring. This process involves saving a workbook to an Office365 OneDrive account and granting access to others.  They show the collaboration process from both the owner and recipient perspective.

episodes.description: Co-authoring a workbook is a great collaboration tool. However, there are some nuances that can make the experience less than perfect. In this episode, Vonne and Justin review the requirements to co-author as well as how to reopen an shared document as an owner and recipient.
episodes.title: Co-authoring: Troubleshooting

But if I know as recipient that JT,
what we did,

It's more of a housekeeping thing,
as well.

00:16:20.595 --> 00:16:23.047
Either they're hiding it or
you are housekeeping to say,

00:16:23.047 --> 00:16:26.150
getting rid of documents that you
know have been unshared with you.

00:16:26.150 --> 00:16:30.905

it doesn't automatically

>> From everything that I can see at

00:16:40.910 --> 00:16:46.543
Because I know, some of those other files,
I know that I hadn't worked with them,

00:16:46.543 --> 00:16:51.869
or I had stopped sharing or deleted it
from JT's account as the owner days ago.

297
00:16:51.869 --> 00:16:54.047

00:16:54.047 --> 00:17:00.965

00:17:00.965 --> 00:17:05.597
I hate doing, I don't really know, but

myself, because I have all these different

00:17:11.600 --> 00:17:14.884
It doesn't seem to just take

302

>> Well, Vonne,
that's definitely good to know.

303

[LAUGH] At this time, I feel I have

what about this, what about that?

Like you said the best way to learn

We've broken this thing so

You guys in an office environment,

[LAUGH] You don't have days to

Well, maybe you spend it but then you've

I was fixing the share

So hopefully this is just letting

Yes, we've filmed two

It's taken maybe 45 minutes for you to

It doesn't blindside you and

That's what I hope to accomplish.

So is there more, maybe.

[LAUGH] But I hadn't found it.

>> [LAUGH]
>> So, no, well,

episodes.description: Vonne and Justin take a closer look at version history when saving a document to a OneDrive account, the autosave feature, and how to open and restore versions. They also talk about some the interesting nuances of version history and how it creates versions.
episodes.title: Version History
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.099 --> 00:00:10.099
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.706 --> 00:00:15.150
Greetings everyone, and welcome back

00:00:15.150 --> 00:00:16.816

we're actually back with more

we're gonna be talking

00:00:31.870 --> 00:00:35.420

under-deliver kinda person.

>> Yeah, cuz I would call it our third

part, maybe our three and a half part

00:01:08.531 --> 00:01:11.105

We've talked all about

I have to really control myself as

But what it does is it is allowing,

When you go ahead and

it will automatically save

33

Now, autosave only happens if

This is not enabled on a locally

Mine's out.

Yeah, and while this is part of

Well, it's gonna give you certain

Okay, and if you're on a Mac,

50
00:03:20.017 --> 00:03:23.757
And then if you have a blow out,
if you wanna say, and

00:03:23.757 --> 00:03:29.287

you can reinstall your computer basically,

52
00:03:29.287 --> 00:03:33.760

So thank you McIntosh and Time Machine,

55

So, that's In a nutshell what

But it equates to a lot of different

And that's where I feel

From my experience,

I cannot [LAUGH] find the rhyme or

I have looked tirelessly for

We've done experiments where we've sat

I did that for 20 minutes, and

we'll try to give you a little

75
00:05:01.478 --> 00:05:04.889
But I'm here to say that the rhyme or

00:05:04.889 --> 00:05:10.236
reason of when you get openable

00:05:10.236 --> 00:05:13.550
it's kind of a little haphazard.

I guess take us through maybe a document

You remember, we sat there and

00:09:20.815 --> 00:09:24.935

00:09:37.430 --> 00:09:38.950
Enter, time and the date.

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne explore implementing data validation inside of Excel 2016 for Mac. Here they will show you how to prevent erroneous data types from being entered by restricting the type of data that a user can insert. They also show you how to create custom error messages and highlight invalid data.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne examine document properties of an Excel 2016 workbook. Here they will discuss the different properties and metadata as well as demonstrate how to add properties. They also show how to check accessibility.

us to call it yet another day.

415
00:21:17.600 --> 00:21:18.900
Thank you for joining us, everyone.

416
00:21:18.900 --> 00:21:21.680
Signing off for OfficeProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

417
00:21:21.680 --> 00:21:22.540
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

418
00:21:22.540 --> 00:21:24.102
>> We'll see you next time.

419
00:21:24.102 --> 00:21:28.718
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne demonstrate how you can customize the Excel 2016 interface to make it more efficient for your workflow. Here you will see how to customize the Ribbon and other options in Excel that can be manipulated for ease of use.
episodes.title: Customize Interface
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

[LAUGH]

they talk about it and

39

No, no, we're gonna log in to Excel and

So we've talked a little bit about this

Well, it's gonna take us

That's why it's in the advanced series,

Yes, you can do that.

46

48

It's totally up to you, okay?

It's to where hey,

maybe I'm using things all day long that
are on a couple of different ribbons,

and wouldn't it be nice if I had all the

So it's kind of like if I put it

that is my custom tab,
that might be a little bit easier.

55

I mean, that's the whole reason why we

57
00:02:30.660 --> 00:02:32.855

58

So, I'm gonna show you how
to customize the ribbon, and

I'll just pick out the points

that because sometimes you can get your
Excel files, and why is it doing this?

64

>> [LAUGH]
>> And it's some weird check box on

00:02:57.427 --> 00:02:58.380

66
00:02:58.380 --> 00:02:59.450
>> That's my favorite.

67
00:02:59.450 --> 00:03:00.030
>> I know, right [LAUGH].

68
00:03:00.030 --> 00:03:01.530
>> My favorite thing ever, yes.

69
00:03:01.530 --> 00:03:04.890

how did it even get to that?

70
00:03:04.890 --> 00:03:07.540
You probably did some weird shortcut,

72
00:03:09.965 --> 00:03:10.793
>> [LAUGH]
>> And

00:03:13.050 --> 00:03:14.109
>> Yeah.
>> [LAUGH]

76

77

So where we can add other commands,

all that kind of fun stuff, so

There's a couple ways we can get to it.

86

If we go into the Excel menu and go to

For example,

Remember, the background removal tab

Why that's on?

102

It's there, that's fine.

And that's where you're going to

So the thing is, you can sit here and

>> Yeah, it's one of those, if you

112

113

>> Yeah, and
then I can get really like, what?

Where is my Sort button?

And you like removed all of them.

[LAUGH]

So you can sit here, and if I really

00:05:41.890 --> 00:05:45.300
Now why would I wanna take something

00:05:45.300 --> 00:05:46.670
I don't know, but you could.

125
00:05:46.670 --> 00:05:50.794

126
00:05:50.794 --> 00:05:51.594
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

127
00:05:51.594 --> 00:05:52.162

00:05:52.162 --> 00:05:52.662

00:05:52.662 --> 00:05:53.163

So

And I could take the cells or
the styles, again,

00:06:06.827 --> 00:06:10.825

00:06:10.825 --> 00:06:15.576
What if I wanted to take this
alignment and rename it Pork, or

00:06:15.576 --> 00:06:18.450

137
00:06:18.450 --> 00:06:19.790
You could come down here and

00:06:19.790 --> 00:06:24.100
a little wheel thing,
little settings, I could rename this.

00:06:24.100 --> 00:06:26.410
And I could, sorry, I zoomed out.

00:06:26.410 --> 00:06:27.240
It's up there.

00:06:27.240 --> 00:06:29.380
So we can name it.

142
00:06:29.380 --> 00:06:30.421
We're gonna go with ham.

143
00:06:30.421 --> 00:06:32.598
[LAUGH]
>> So we click on Save and

00:06:32.598 --> 00:06:34.580

145
00:06:34.580 --> 00:06:36.970
All right, cuz that makes so much sense.

But you can see that you can

00:06:39.410 --> 00:06:42.100
You could go ahead and

148

You could take out whole groups.

149
00:06:44.000 --> 00:06:47.470

150
00:06:47.470 --> 00:06:48.540
Me personally,

I probably wouldn't mess with any of

00:06:51.930 --> 00:06:57.900
That was just why it's there, but

What I would do is make my own ribbon tab.

154

So I can come down here, and if I click on

And so there's my new tab, and notice

00:07:18.780 --> 00:07:22.240

158
00:07:22.240 --> 00:07:28.500
So it's like you gotta have those levels,

159
00:07:28.500 --> 00:07:31.115
Okay, so
that's my techiness coming out in there.

160
00:07:31.115 --> 00:07:32.532

161
00:07:32.532 --> 00:07:37.010

00:07:37.010 --> 00:07:41.810
So we'll go ahead and take this and we can

00:07:41.810 --> 00:07:43.520
I'm sorry, I zoomed out.

164
00:07:43.520 --> 00:07:47.470
We can name it My Tools, all right?

165
00:07:47.470 --> 00:07:48.986
And then the whole tab name.

00:07:48.986 --> 00:07:52.386
So it's all about what
you're selected on and

167

add, remove, or rename it.

168
00:07:56.842 --> 00:08:04.770
And I can just name it Vonne's cool stuff,

169
00:08:04.770 --> 00:08:07.651
And then I go through,

00:08:07.651 --> 00:08:11.406
I find the commands that I want to

171
00:08:11.406 --> 00:08:16.313
And I could make more groups, right,
I could have the my tools, and

172
00:08:16.313 --> 00:08:18.047
I can then rename this.

173
00:08:18.047 --> 00:08:21.809
I can name it image stuff.

174
00:08:21.809 --> 00:08:24.117
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm being really descriptive, [LAUGH].

175
00:08:24.117 --> 00:08:27.662
And then depending on which
group I have selected,

176
00:08:27.662 --> 00:08:32.900
I'm just gonna randomly grab different

177
00:08:32.900 --> 00:08:37.567
Notice I can choose from different

178
00:08:37.567 --> 00:08:39.713

179
00:08:39.713 --> 00:08:43.079
That's sometimes where I know that
they exist and maybe it's in a menu,

180
00:08:43.079 --> 00:08:45.690
but I don't wanna keep going to the menu.

181
00:08:45.690 --> 00:08:48.630
You can have this option like
anything that's not in the ribbon,

182
00:08:48.630 --> 00:08:50.260
let me go ahead and put in there.

183
00:08:50.260 --> 00:08:55.920
That's fine too, because maybe I wanted
a five point star, I don't know.

184
00:08:55.920 --> 00:08:58.828
I'm not sure if I really need all
of these, but you get the idea.

185
00:08:58.828 --> 00:09:00.064
>> The idea, yeah.

186
00:09:00.064 --> 00:09:02.811
>> You move over, you make your groups,
you make your tabs.

187
00:09:02.811 --> 00:09:05.780
You could move them up and
down if you wanted to.

188
00:09:05.780 --> 00:09:11.280
I can see and I can drag this where
it's below the home tab or above.

189
00:09:11.280 --> 00:09:15.180
Here, let me gonna ahead and make,
oops, come on, let's, come on.

190
00:09:15.180 --> 00:09:19.320
[LAUGH] We will move this down,
we'll make it easier on myself.

191
00:09:19.320 --> 00:09:24.150
Okay, there we go, well,
anyways, click and drag.

192
00:09:24.150 --> 00:09:28.338
It keeps on expanding them and
it's not wanting to let me do that.

193
00:09:28.338 --> 00:09:32.580
But I bet if I grab it really quickly,
okay, you know what?

194
00:09:32.580 --> 00:09:35.496
It's fine where it goes,
that's great, [LAUGH] you know what,

195
00:09:35.496 --> 00:09:36.901
I won't mess with it too much.

196
00:09:36.901 --> 00:09:40.312
>> You get anywhere near those little
triangles, and it's just like, expand.

197
00:09:40.312 --> 00:09:42.339
>> Yeah, I know,
I'm just like, [SOUND] okay, so

198
00:09:42.339 --> 00:09:45.154
I've had a little rough time going
on that, but you get the idea.

199
00:09:45.154 --> 00:09:49.196
And you could drag and drop it if you want
to, I don't really wanna fight with it,

200
00:09:49.196 --> 00:09:51.850
honestly, so I'm just gonna let it be.

201
00:09:51.850 --> 00:09:55.598
There is something down here when
you get into macros and things.

202
00:09:55.598 --> 00:10:00.353
That if you wanted to record macros,
you have to turn on the developer tab,

203
00:10:00.353 --> 00:10:02.325
notice it is not on by default.

204
00:10:02.325 --> 00:10:06.307
So if you ever needed even if it's just
that, you just need to turn the developer,

205
00:10:06.307 --> 00:10:10.368
you come into the ribbon, turn it on, and
then you can turn on and off other things.

206
00:10:10.368 --> 00:10:14.735
If I click Save,
then it will go ahead and do all that,

207
00:10:14.735 --> 00:10:17.980
now remember I removed all of that.

208
00:10:17.980 --> 00:10:21.330
I'm like, my gosh, I removed
the font group, and the align group.

209
00:10:21.330 --> 00:10:25.545
That's bad, and then Vonne's cool stuff,
yeah, that's there too, but you know what,

210
00:10:25.545 --> 00:10:26.819
I kind of really miss this.

211
00:10:26.819 --> 00:10:33.642
So I took out a lot of important commands,
if you're like, uh-oh, what did I do?

212
00:10:33.642 --> 00:10:36.453
Luckily, if you wanted to, like I do,

213
00:10:36.453 --> 00:10:41.074
you can come back into your preferences,

214

And then down here on the ribbon toolbar,
well, the ribbon,

00:10:44.432 --> 00:10:47.770
not the toolbar part,
that little wheel down there.

216
00:10:47.770 --> 00:10:51.840
There's a really great way that you
can reset all of your customizations,

217
00:10:51.840 --> 00:10:52.600
that's really good.

218
00:10:52.600 --> 00:10:55.580
Now notice there are two
different parts right here.

219
00:10:55.580 --> 00:11:00.318
There is a reset all customizations,
or reset only the ribbon.

220
00:11:00.318 --> 00:11:05.214
Cuz the quick access toolbar and
the ribbon are separate, so

221
00:11:05.214 --> 00:11:09.430
you can reset either one,
or do all of them.

222
00:11:09.430 --> 00:11:11.450
